choices.text: Failure of perforation of anal membrane
Incomplete separation of cloaca by urorectal septum
Failure of recanalization of the colon

questions.text: A newborn boy had no passage of meconium for two days after birth. Examination revealed anal agenesis with perineal fistula. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Incomplete separation of cloaca by the urorectal septum causes anal agenesis.

When the urorectal septum is formed, the cloacal membrane gets divided into urogenital membrane anteriorly and anal membrane posteriorly. The ectoderm in the region of the future anal opening is called proctodeum. The proctodeum invaginates and creates the anal pit. The anal membrane now separates the hindgut from the anal pit.

Formation of the anal canal takes place as follows:

  • The upper part of the anal canal is formed by the endodermal hindgut and the lower part by the ectodermal anal pit.
  • The anal membrane in between breaks around the 9th week and the anal canal becomes continuous.
  • The junction between the endodermal and the ectodermal region of the anal canal is marked by the pectinate line.

Reference: Textbook of Langman's, 12th Edition, Digestive System Embryology, Page number - 208

questions.text: A 23-year-old man complains of nasal obstruction, bloody nose, cough, and bloody sputum. A chest X-ray displays cavitated lesions and multiple nodules within both lung fields. Urinalysis reveals 3+ hematuria and red blood cell casts. Laboratory studies show anemia and elevated serum levels of C-ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody). Peripheral eosinophils are not increased. A renal biopsy was performed and histopathological image is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological images show crescent which is seen in rapidly proliferative glomerulonephritis.

  • The classic histologic picture is one of enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli. The hypercellularity is caused by
    1. Infiltration by leukocytes, both neutrophils and monocytes;
    2. Proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.
  • The glomeruli often show focal and segmental necrosis, and variably show diffuse or focal endothelial proliferation, and mesangial proliferation. Segmental glomerular necrosis and distinctive crescents.
  • In classic MPGN, histologic picture is one of enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli. The hypercellularity is caused by
    1. Infiltration by leukocytes, both neutrophils and monocytes;
    2. Proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.
  • By light microscopy, the glomeruli either appears normal in the early stages of the disease or exhibit uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall.

Reference: Robbins, 10th Ed, pg 910

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman is given a prescription of fluconazole to be taken daily (q 12 h) for 3 days. The half-life is 12 h. How long will it take for the medication to reach 90% of its final steady state level?
questions.solution:
To calculate the time, it takes for a medication to reach 90% of its final steady state, you can use the formula (3.3) * (t1/2).

Given that the half-life (t1/2) of fluconazole is 12 hours:

Time to Reach 90% of Steady State = (3.3) * (12 hours) = 39.6 hours

So, it will take approximately 39.6 hours for the medication to reach 90% of its final steady-state level. Among the given options, the closest one is:

C) 40 hours

This option is the most accurate representation of the calculated time of approximately 39.6 hours.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology by Bertram G. Katzung, Fourteenth Edition, Pg no. 51

questions.text: An intravenous pyelogram (IVP) showing hydronephrosis in the work up of a patient with cervical cancer otherwise confined to a cervix of normal size would indicate stage:
questions.solution:
Now here - the investigation done is IVP which is one of the recommended investigations by FIGO therefore results of IVP are important for staging. By definition, a positive IVP would mean ureter is involved i.e extension to pelvic side wall and i.e Stage 111 b.

Such staging applies even if there is no palpable tumor beyond the cervix.

Remember - FIGO stage is based on careful clinical examination and the results of specific radiological studies and procedures. These should be performed, and stage should be assigned before any definitive therapy is administered. The clinical stage should never be changed on the basis of subsequent findings.

Reference: Dutta Gynae, 6th ed, pg 195

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with Alzheimer disease is brought with abdominal cramps, diarrhoea, diaphoresis, and muscular weakness and spasms in his extremities. He has ingested excessive amount of medications in a suicide attempt. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 51/min, respirations are 12/min and labored, and blood pressure is 88/56 mm Hg. Treatment is initiated. Shortly after, most of his symptoms have resolved, but he continues to have muscular spasms. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of muscarinic acetylcholine excess (e.g., diarrhea, diaphoresis, bradycardia, bronchospasm, salivation, lacrimation, miosis) and nicotinic acetylcholine excess (e.g., muscle weakness). Atropine can only reverse the muscarinic effects.

When taken in excess, medications for Alzheimer disease such as donepezil can result in symptoms similar to that of organophosphate poisoning. In such cases, pralidoxime is given to restore activity of acetylcholinesterase, which then catalyzes the breakdown of excessive acetylcholine to reverse symptoms. Atropine does not act on nicotinic cholinergic receptors and thus cannot treat symptoms of neuromuscular dysfunction, for which pralidoxime is still necessary.

Pralidoxime has poor blood-brain barrier penetration and can lead to a transient worsening of acetylcholinesterase inhibition following administration, which is why atropine is typically administered first to treat CNS symptoms and prevent further acetylcholinesterase inhibition.

Management of patient with suspected OP poisoning

  • Patient decontamination (e.g., remove clothes, wash skin)
  • Secure airways, oxygen therapy, ECG
  • Measurement of erythrocyte cholinesterase activity: ↓ acetylcholinesterase activity
  • Medication
    • Atropine
    • Oximes: pralidoxime (2-PAM), obidoxime
      • Regenerate acetylcholinesterase by dephosphorylation
      • Function peripherally on both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors
      • Should only be administered after atropine due to risk of transient worsening of acetylcholinesterase inhibition
    • Benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam): to control organophosphate-induced seizures.

A & B: They would further exacerbate this patient's symptoms of acetylcholine excess and must be avoided in this patient.

C: Benztropine is a selective antagonist of muscarinic receptors that particularly decreases cholinergic overactivity in the CNS. It is typically used to treat tremor in Parkinson disease and extrapyramidal symptoms caused by antipsychotics. However, since this patient's muscarinic symptoms have mostly resolved following the administration of atropine, an additional muscarinic inhibitor would not be particularly useful.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition by Bertram G. Katzung, Pg no. 114

questions.text: OCP's intake causes all Except:
questions.solution:
OCP's have an antiovulatory effect and by virtue of this property, relieve dysmenorrhea (rather than causing it), premenstrual tension and Mittelschmerz syndrome.

Side effects of OCPs are:

Cancers related to OCP use:

  • Carcinoma cervix
  • Hepatic adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma (+/-)
  • Breast cancer (+/-)

Note:

  • OCPs are protective against STDs
  • OCPs are protective against PID

"The risk of hospitalization for PID is reduced by approximately 50-60% but at least 12 months of use are necessary and the protection is limited to current use".

-Leon Speroff, 7th/ed, p 905

  • At present time, no known association exists between oral contraception and viral sexually transmitted infections.

Reference: Dutta Obs, 6th/ed, p 545; Shaw, 14th/ed, p 208

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with diabetes presents to clinic for a routine checkup. His blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. His last urinalysis showed a urine micro-albumin of 150 mcg. What is the most appropriate initial antihypertensive for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient with diabetes has been diagnosed with hypertension and diabetic nephropathy. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are the first-choice medications for patients with diabetes and hypertension. This is caused by the combined effect of ACE inhibitors as an antihypertensive and its renal protective effects.
  • Option(A): Doxazosin is an alpha1-selective-blocker that is used to treat hypertension as well as urinary retention secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia.
  • Option(B): Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that is the most common initial medication for essential hypertension. Because of the patient having diabetes with the initial stages of protein-losing nephropathy, lisinopril is a better choice as the initial antihypertensive.
  • Option(D): Metoprolol is a beta1-selective blocker that may be used as an initial antihypertensive in patients with compensated CHF or history of coronary artery disease.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition by Bertram G. Katzung, Pg. no. 176

questions.text: A 32-year-old man has a history of frequent episodes of renal colic with calcium-containing renal stones. A careful workup indicates that he has a defect in proximal tubular calcium reabsorption, which results in high concentrations of calcium salts in the tubular urine. The most useful diuretic agent in the treatment of recurrent calcium stones is
questions.solution:
• The thiazides are useful in the prevention of calcium stones because these drugs reduce tubular calcium concentration, probably by increasing passive proximal tubular and distal convoluted tubule reabsorption of calcium.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition By Bertram G. Katzung, Pg no. 271

choices.text: 7-methyl guanosine cap at their 5' terminus
Attachment of CCA terminal at the 3' end

questions.text: All of the following are post transcriptional modification done for messenger RNA, except:
questions.solution:
Messenger RNA Is Modified at the 5' & 3' Ends

Option A: The Coding Portions (Exons) of Most Eukaryotic mRNA Encoding Genes Are Interrupted by Introns, so Introns Are Removed & Exons Are Spliced Together during formation of mRNA molecules.

Option B: Eukaryotic mRNAs contain a 7-methylguanosine cap structure at their 5' terminus. The cap structure is added to the 5' end of the newly transcribed mRNA precursor in the nucleus very soon after synthesis and prior to transport of the mRNA molecule to the cytoplasm. The 5' cap of the RNA transcript is required both for efficient translation initiation and protection of the 5' end of mRNA from attack by 5' → 3' exonucleases. The secondary methylations of mRNA molecules, those on the 2'-hydroxy and the N7 of adenylyl residues, occur after the mRNA molecule has appeared in the cytoplasm.

Option C: Eukaryotic mRNAs also have a poly(A) tail at the 3' terminus. Poly(A) tails are added to the 3' end of mRNA molecules in a posttranscriptional processing step. Following nuclear transport, cytoplasmic enzymes in mammalian cells can both add and remove adenylyl residues from the poly(A) tails; this process has been associated with an alteration of mRNA stability and translatability.

Option D: Attachment of the CCA terminal at the 3' end is done in tRNA, not in mRNA. The characteristic CpCpAOH terminal at the 3' end of the tRNA is attached by the enzyme nucleotidyl transferase. The 3' OH of the A ribose is the point of attachment for the specific amino acid that is to enter the polymerization reaction of protein synthesis. The methylation of mammalian tRNA precursors probably occurs in the nucleus, whereas the cleavage and attachment of CpCpAOH are cytoplasmic functions, since the terminal nucleotides turn over more rapidly than do the tRNA molecules themselves. Specific aminoacyl tRNA synthetases within the cytoplasm of mammalian cells are required for the attachment of the different amino acids to the CpCpAOH residues.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 32nd edition, CH 36, PN 390

questions.text: All are the uses of below instrument except:
questions.solution:
KOCHER'S CLAMP

Material: Stainless steel

Sterilization: Autoclaving and boiling

The blades may be curved or flat or straight. One blade has a longitudinal ridge which fits in a longitudinal groove on the other blade. It has transverse serrations on its blade.

Uses

Hysterectomy

To damp the uterosacral ligaments, uterine blood vessels and the cornual structures or the infundibulopelvic ligaments in vaginal hysterectomy.

  • Oophorectomy for ovarian cysts or tumors
  • Removal of pedunculated leiomyomatous polyps
  • Salpingectomy for tubal ectopic gestation
  • Caesarean hysterectomy
  • Clamping the umbilical cord of the newborn
  • Artificial low rupture of membranes
  • To hold the uterus during abdominal hysterectomy

Reference: L JB Sharma textbook of gynecology, e1, p 788

questions.text: A case of 35-week pregnancy with hydramnios and marked respiratory distress is best treated by:
questions.solution:
The patient in the question has marked respiratory distress (i.e. it is a severe polyhydramnios and requires treatment) and gestational age is 35 weeks (i.e., fetal maturity is not yet achieved).

So our aim should be to relieve the distress of patients in hope of continuing the pregnancy till at least 37 weeks.

This can be achieved by:

  • Amniocentesis or
  • Use of Indomethacin

Amniocentesis:

  • The main aim of amniocentesis is to relieve maternal distress with the added advantage that lung maturity of fetus can be predicted by Lecithin/Sphingomyelin ratio in the expressed fluid.
  • Slow decompression is done at the rate of 500 ml/hr.
  • Maximum fluid removed is 1.5 - 2 litres.

Use of Indomethacin - Indomethacin should not be used for more than 32 weeks because it leads to premature closure of ductus arteriosus.

Amniotomy: The main disadvantage of amniotomy is the possibility of cord prolapse and placental abruption. Slow removal fluid by amniocentesis helps to obviate these dangers.

- Williams Obs, 22/e, p 530, 23/e, p 495

Reference: Dutta Obs, 7/e, p 214; Williams Obs, 22/e, p 529, 530, 23/e, p 494, 495

questions.text: A 36-year-old obese woman has been experiencing heartburn from gastric reflux for the past 5 years after eating large meals. She undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and a biopsy specimen of the distal esophagus is obtained. Which of the following stain shown in figure can help in making the diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Inflammation from reflux of gastric acid has resulted in replacement of normal esophageal squamous epithelium by intestinal-type columnar epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Such conversion of one adult cell type into another cell type is called metaplasia and it occurs when stimuli reprogram stem cells.
  • These goblet cells contain acidic mucin picked by alcian blue.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th edition, Chapter - 2, pg 34

questions.text: Monitoring of Beta-hCG is useful in management of all except:
questions.solution:
b-hCG levels are helpful in monitoring:

  1. H. mole: 'A method of detecting the persistent mole and development of choriocarcinoma is by estimating hCG in the serum urine'. - Shaw, 14/e, p 231
  2. Choriocarcinoma: b-hCG is a specific marker for choriocarcinoma. The levels of b-hCG are monitored following chemotherapy and complete regression of tumor is indicated when three consecutive weekly radioimmunoassays of hCG in serum are negative. - Shaw, 14/e, p 235
  3. Ectopic pregnancy: In case of unruptured ectopic pregnancy which is managed medically with methotrexate or by conservative surgery-monitoring is done by estimating b-hCG levels. 'Following conservative surgery or medical treatment, estimation of b-hCG should be done weekly till the value becomes< 5.0 mIU/ml' - Dutta Obs, 6/e, p 191
  4. Endodermal sinus tumor - 'These tumors are yolk sac tumors and their markers are Alpha fetoprotein and antitrypsin their levels and not beta-hCG. So hCG levels are not used for monitoring.

Reference: Shaw, 14/e, p 231, 235, 380; Dutta Obs, 7/e, p 59

questions.text: A primigravida with full term pregnancy in labor for 1 day is brought to casualty. On examination she is dehydrated, slightly pale, pulse 100/min, BP120/80 mm Hg. abdominal examination reveals a fundal height of 36 weeks, cephalic presentation, foetal heart absent, mild uterine contractions present. On P/V examination, cervix is fully dilated, head is at +1 station, caput with moulding present, pelvis adequate. Dirty, infected discharge is present. What would be the best management option after initial work-up?
questions.solution:
• Patient is primigravida
  • On examination:
    • Dehydration is present
    • P/R is 100/min, i.e. tachycardia present.

PIA

  • Fundal height-36 weeks
  • Presentation-cephalic
  • FHS-Absent
  • Mild uterine contractions are present.

P/V

  • Cervix-fully dilated
  • Station = + 1
  • Caput present
  • Moulding present
  • Dirty infected discharge is present.

Most importantly - Pelvis is adequate.

This patient is undoubtedly a case of obstructed labour. As we all know in nulliparous females in case of obstructed labour- a state of uterine exhaustion is manifested as weakened uterine conditions.

  • In such cases, if oxytocin drip is given it may lead to rupture of uterus as lower segment is thinned out (i.e. option 'b' ruled out).
  • Craniotomy and other destructive procedures are not carried out in modern obstetrics (i.e., option 'd' ruled out).

Mgt: of obstructed labor caesarean section.

Reference: Dutta Obs., 7/e, p 358-360

choices.text: Pleomorphism and nucleomegaly with high N: C ratio
Increased mitosis, frequent at abnormal locations(other than basal)

questions.text: Following statements are true for defining Dysplasia EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Dysplastic epithelium is recognized by a loss in the uniformity of individual cells and in their architectural orientation.
  • Dysplastic cells exhibit considerable pleomorphism and often possess abnormally large, hyperchromatic nuclei.
  • Mitotic figures are more abundant than usual and frequently appear in abnormal locations within the epithelium.
  • In dysplastic stratified squamous epithelium, mitoses are not confined to the basal layers, where they normally occur, but may be seen throughout the epithelium.
  • For example, the usual progressive maturation of tall cells in the basal layer to flattened squamous on the surface may be lost and replaced by a disordered hodgepodge of dark basal-appearing cells.
  • When dysplastic changes are severe and involve the entire thickness of the epithelium, the lesion is referred to as carcinoma in situ, a preinvasive stage of cancer.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 194.

choices.text: Immediate clamping, cutting and ligation of cord

questions.text: Which is not included in active management of III stage of Labour?
questions.solution:
Active management of the third stage of labour includes:

  1. Administration of a uterotonic soon after birth (best is oxytocin) followed by misoprostol
  2. Delayed cord damping
  3. Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction
  4. Uterine massage.

Now this leaves us with no doubt that 'Early cord clamping' should not be included in active management of labour. Reason - why early cord clamping is being discouraged is because if cord is clamped immediately the cord blood present in it (80-100 ml) will go waste whereas, if delayed cord clamping is done, the cord blood goes to the newborn and there are less chances of anemia, intraventricular hemorrhage and late onset sepsis especially in preterm infants.

Also remember: Inorder to facilitate the cord blood to reach the newborn, the tray with the baby should be placed at a lower level than the mother's abdomen after delivery and before cord is cut.

Reference: Dutta Obs, 7/e, pg 141, 142; Sheila Balakrishnan, 1/e, pg 149; Management of Labour by Arulkumaran; Penna & Rao, 2/e, p 196, Recent Advances in Obs and Gynae, Vol 24, edited by William Dunlop, pg 93

questions.text: Which of the following radiations is/are responsible for cancer?
questions.solution:
• Exposure to UV rays derived from the sun is associated with cancer.
  • The UV portion of solar spectrum can be divided into three wavelength range: UV-A(320-400nm), UV-B(280-320nm), UV-C(200-280nm).
  • Of these, UV-B is responsible for the induction of cutaneous cancers.
  • Invisible rays that are part of the energy that comes from the sun. Ultraviolet B radiation causes sunburn, darkening and thickening of the outer layer of the skin and melanoma and other types of skin cancer.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 324.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Down Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Caudal Regression Syndrome (CRS), also called as Sacral Agenesis, is rare in general population, but more common in infants of diabetic mothers (specific for these babies). It has not been described in Down Syndrome.

Regarding other options, as per OP Ghai, 10th Ed.

Option B: Linear growth is retarded in Down Syndrome

Option C: About 13-34% patients with Down syndrome have hypothyroidism.

Option D: 40-60% patients have conductive hearing loss and are prone to Serous Otitis Media - Commonly during the first year.

Reference: OP Ghai, 10th Edition, Page 667

questions.text: A normal infant is able to sit leaning forward with hands, reaches for and grasps cube with one hand, transfers objects between hands, cannot wave bye-bye, cannot hold objects between finger and thumb. Most probable age is?
questions.solution:
Let us evaluate the information given in the question.

  • A normal infant can sit with own support from 6 months onwards, also called as Tripod position.
  • Reaching for and grasping a cube with one hand, also called as Unidextrous grasp comes at 6 months of age
  • Transferring objects hands to hands develops between 6 to 7 months of age.
  • Waving bye-bye develops at 9 months
  • Immature Pincer grasp comes by 9 months and mature one by 12 months.

So, the child is able to do milestones of at or before 7 months of age, but not attained milestones related to 9 months and beyond. Hence the probable age of the child is 7 months.

References: OP Ghai, 10th Edition, Tables 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 3.4; Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, pg-69

questions.text: Fragile X syndrome is characterized by all Except:
questions.solution:
• Fragile X syndrome is the prototype of diseases in which the causative mutation occurs in a long repeating sequence of three nucleotides.(CGG)
  • Fragile X syndrome results from a mutation in the FMR1 gene, which maps to Xq27.3 and is the second most common genetic cause of mental retardation, after Down syndrome.
  • The typical physical phenotype includes a long face with a large mandible, large everted ears and large testicles(macroorchidism).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases, 10th ed, Pg: 269

questions.text: A 34 year old male presented with complaints of burning and itching over thigh with skin lesion. There was a history of painkiller tablet consumption before 1 day. Similar history of skin lesion over the same site before 2 years. The condition shown in the image is____
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is Fixed drug eruption. It occurs at the same site on repeat exposure of drug. It is common due to NSAIDS (Option D)

Fixed drug eruption (FDE)

  • Based on delayed (type 4) hypersensitivity reaction
  • Sites - mucosa of oral cavity, genital area, trunk and extremities
  • Drug taken for the 1st time - it takes 8 - 10 days for FDE to occur, but re intake of same drug again produces FDE in 30mins to 5 hours
  • This reaction recurs at the same site and heals with hyperpigmentation
  • Treatment - stop the offending drug, start on steroids

Option A - Tinea corporis is erythematous scaly annular lesions cause by dermatophyte infection. It is associated with itching

Option B - Granuloma annulare is a common inflammatory skin condition typified clinically by annular, smooth, discoloured papules and plaques, and necrobiotic granulomas on histology.

Option C - BT leprosy lesions are erythematous asymmetric plaques with satellite lesions associated with decreased touch temperature sensation over plaque.

Source: Drug reaction

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, 118.11

questions.text: What happens in case of "Vasopressin escape" on SIADH?
questions.solution:
• In SIADH, to prevent the overactivity of ADH, Kidney adapts by down regulating the production and insertion of Aquaporin-2 channel proteins

questions.text: True about Ca vulva associated/predisposed by:
questions.solution:
Premalignant lesion of vulva:

  • Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia VIN (most common) Paget's disease
  • Chronic vulvar dystrophies Condyloma accuminata

Bowen's disease is a type of VIN where among the ordinary atypical cells, large bloated cells called Bowen cells are also present.

questions.text: Calculate FEV1, from the below spirometry reading?
questions.solution:
Forced vital capacity (FVC)

  • It is the volume of air in liters that can be forcefully and maximally exhaled after a maximal inspiration

Forced Expiratory Volume in the 1st Second (FEV1)

  • It is the volume of air that is exhaled in the 1st second of the FVC
  • Normally it is around 80% of the FVC

Here, in this question:

  • FVC = 5L
  • FEV1 = 4 L
  • So, FEV1 4/5 = 80% of FVC

Reference: Ganong, 25th edition, page no. 630

questions.text: The type of joint marked in the given image below is?
questions.solution:
The joint marked in the above image is the costotransverse joint, which is a synovial type of joint.

The joints of thorax are as follows:

Majority - plane type of synovial joint (sternocostal, interchondral, costotransverse, costovertebral joints)

Exceptions-

  • 1st sternocostal joint - fibrous joint (synarthrosis joint)
  • Sternoclavicular joint - saddle type of synovial joint
  • Midline joints (manubriosternal joint and xiphisternal joint) - secondary cartilaginous joints
  • Costochondral joint - primary cartilaginous joints

Reference: Textbook of B D Chaurasia's handbook of General Anatomy, 4th Edition, Page number - 57

questions.text:
All are true about ketosis and their tests except?
A. Rothera's test is answered by acetoacetate and acetone
B. Beta hydroxybutyrate is the major ketone body in ketosis
C. Gerhardt's test is answered by Acetoacetate
D. In normal people the ratio of BHB to Acetoacetate is 1:1
questions.solution:
A: Rothera's test: Development of a purple ring at the junction of the two liquids indicates the presence of acetone or acetoacetic acid in urine. It is not answered by beta hydroxybutyrate. Strip tests based on the same principle are also available.

B: Beta hydroxybutyrate is produced from acetoacetate which is the major ketone body in ketoacidosis.

C: Gerhadt's test for acetoacetic acid: To 5 ml of urine, add dilute ferric chloride solution drop by drop, till a maximum precipitate of ferric phosphate is obtained. This is to eliminate the phosphates which may obscure the color in the test. Filter. To the filtrate add excess ferric chloride. A red color indicates the presence of acetoacetic acid.

D: The ratio of BHB to Acetoacetate is generally 3:1

So, statements in options A, B & C are correct, while option D is wrong.

Reference: DM Vasudevan-textbook of biochemistry, page 196.

Reference: LIPPINCOTT illustrated reviews 6th edition biochemistry page 145.

questions.text: Gene for major histocompatibility complex is located on which chromosome?
questions.solution:
• The human major histocompatibility complex(MHC) commonly called as human leukocyte antigen(HLA) complex is a 4 megabase region on chromosome 6p.
  • The major histocompatibility complex(mhc) is a group of genes that encode proteins on the cell surface that have an important role in immune response.
  • Their main role is in antigen presentation where mhc molecules display peptide fragments for recognition by appropriate t-cells.

Reference: Harrison, 17th ed, Pg: 2045

questions.text: Cromolyn and nedocromil is used as nasal spray and eye drops in reducing symptoms of ___.
questions.solution:
When taken regularly (two to four puffs two to four times daily) by patients with perennial (non-seasonal) asthma, both agents modestly but significantly reduce symptomatic severity and the need for bronchodilator medications, particularly in young patients with extrinsic asthma.

These drugs are not as potent nor as predictably effective as inhaled corticosteroids, and the only way of determining whether a patient will respond is by a therapeutic trial of 4 weeks' duration.

Cromolyn and nedocromil solutions are also useful in reducing symptoms of allergic rhino conjunctivitis.

Applying the solution by nasal spray or eye drops several times a day is effective in about 75% of patients, even during the peak pollen season.

Reference: LANG' Basic & clinical pharmacology by Bertram G. Katzung, Susen B. Masters and Anthony J. Trevor 12th edition. Chapter 20- Drugs used in asthma by Dr. Homer A. Boushy, MD. Page no. 349

questions.text: Effect of cholecystokinin on GIT-
questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin
Source: I cells (duodenum, jejunum)

Action:

  • ↓ pancreatic secretion
  • ↓ gallbladder contraction
  • ↓ gastric emptying
  • ↑ sphincter of Oddi relaxation
  • ↑ intestinal peristalsis

Regulation:
Secretion of cck ↑ by fatty acids, amino acids

Note: Acts on neural muscarinic pathways to cause pancreatic secretion

Reference: Ganong, 25th edition page no.455, 471

questions.text: HELLP syndrome includes all except:
questions.solution:
HELLP syndrome is a variant of preeclampsia which includes

Hemolysis: burr cells and schistocytes in peripheral smear, elevated bilirubin

Elevated liver enzymes: LDH>600 IU/L, AST, ALT>70 IU/L

Thrombocytopenia: platelet count <1 lac/cmm

Decreased haptoglobin

Reference: Arias 5th edition pg no 208

Postpartum prophylaxis

  • If baby is Rh positive and mother Rh negative, 300 µg of Anti D immunoglobulin (IgG) is given to mother.
  • Postpartum prophylaxis is best given within 72 hours after delivery but it can be given till 28 days after delivery Option b and d are correct.

"Although Rh IgG generally should be given within 72 hours after delivery, it has shown to be effective in preventing isoimmunization if given upto 28 days after delivery"

-COGDT 10/e, p 284 Anti D immunoglobulin is not helpful in case of ABO incompatibility.

Also Know:

Role of postpartum prophylaxis:

  • Anti D immunoglobulin given postpartum binds to antigen sites on the fetal red cells so that these cells cannot mount an immune response and thus prevent future sensitisation and next pregnancy.
  • If after delivery, the fetus has a positive direct Coombs test, it means that the mother is already immunized. In such cases, there is no point in giving anti D.

Reference: Dutta Obs. 7/e, pg 334; COGDT 10/e, pg 284

questions.text: Codeine, oxycodone and hydroxycodone undergo metabolism in liver by _________.
questions.solution:
• Hepatic oxidative metabolism is the primary route of degradation of the phenylpiperidine opioids (meperidine, fentanyl, alfentanil, sufentanil) and eventually leaves only small quantities of the parent compound unchanged for excretion. However, accumulation of a demethylated metabolite of meperidine, normeperidine, may occur in patients with decreased renal function and in those receiving multiple high doses of the drug.
  • In high concentrations, normeperidine may cause seizures. In contrast, no active metabolites of fentanyl have been reported. The P450 isozyme CYP3A4 metabolizes fentanyl by N -dealkylation in the liver.
  • CYP3A4 also present in the mucosa of the small intestine and contributes to the first-pass metabolism of fentanyl when it is taken orally. Codeine, oxycodone, and hydrocodone undergo metabolism in the liver by P450 isozyme CYP2D6, resulting in the production of metabolites of greater potency. For example, codeine is demethylated to morphine. Genetic polymorphism of CYP2D6 has been documented and linked to the variation in analgesic response seen among patients.

Reference: LANG' Basic & clinical pharmacology by Bertram G. Katzung, Susen B. Masters and Anthony J. Trevor 12th edition. Chapter 31- Opioid Analgesics & Antagonists by Dr. Mark A. Schumacher,PhD,MD, Dr. Alan I. Basbaum,PhD,& Dr. Walter L. Way,MD. Page no. 546

questions.text: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of which of the following enzymes after addition of FAD in vitro?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thiamine diphosphate is also the coenzyme for transketolase, in the pentose phosphate pathway. The activation of transketolase in erythrocyte lysate by thiamine diphosphate added in vitro has become the accepted index of thiamine nutritional status.

Option B: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by the measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Option C: Vitamin B6 status is assessed by assaying erythrocyte transaminases. The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by the activation of erythrocyte transaminases by pyridoxal phosphate added in vitro.

questions.text: Regarding childhood UTI, all of the following are true except?
questions.solution:
Let us evaluate each option individually

Option A is False. UTIs are caused primarily by colonic bacteria as per Nelson. Escherichia coli causes 54-67% of all UTIs, followed by Klebsiella spp. and Proteus spp., Enterococcus, and Pseudomonas. Other bacteria known to cause UTIs include Staphylococcus saprophyticus, group B streptococcus, and, less commonly, Staphylococcus aureus, Candida spp., and Salmonella spp.

Option B is True. All recurrent UTI need USG Abdomen after therapy is over, to rule out any bladder-related anatomic abnormality as a cause of recurrent UTI.

Option C is True. AAP Practice Recommendations as well as Nelson suggest that MCU, also called VCUG, is recommended in recurrent UTI as a part of work-up for likely etiology & rule out Vesico-Ureteric Reflux (VUR).

Option D is True. In a child with recurrent UTIs, identification of predisposing factors is beneficial. Bowel and bladder dysfunction is a very important contributor to recurrent UTIs and is one of the main reasons for an increase in UTIs around the time of toilet training.

Reference: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 553

questions.text: A baby was born to a HIV+ mother, who was not taking antiretroviral therapy. The baby was started on exclusive breastfeeds. What should be the initial prophylaxis to start in the baby according to the latest guidelines?
questions.solution:
Guidelines for HIV according to NACO 2021 & WHO Updated Guidelines

  • Any baby born to HIV+ mother is labelled as HIV-exposed infant, regardless of the infection status
  • All HIV-exposed infants are preferably started on exclusive breast feeds (EBF). If EBF is not possible or available, exclusive replacement feeding (ERF) can be considered, provided the family has resources and are motivated enough to continue the same.
  • All HIV-exposed infants are categorised into low-risk and high-risk as follows:
  • All HIV-exposed infants need to be started on Anti-Retroviral (ARV) Prophylaxis
  • In low-risk infants, we start oral nevirapine daily for 6 weeks
  • In high-risk infants, we start combination therapy using oral nevirapine + oral zidovudine.
  • While using combination therapy, the duration for ARV Prophylaxis depends on the mode of feeding. For EBF, it is 12 weeks, while for ERF, it is 6 weeks.

Reference: NACO 2021 Update, Table 3.1.7, Page 180; OP Ghai 10th Edition, Pages 248-250

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Melanoma (the most malignant skin cancer), melanocytic nevi (the most common benign skin tumor) (Choice D), and dysplastic nevi (in between nevi and melanoma) all result from melanocytes.

Melanoma, also redundantly known as malignant melanoma, is a type of skin cancer that develops from the pigment-producing cells known as melanocytes

  • A is for Asymmetry.
  • B is for Border. Melanoma borders tend to be uneven and may have scalloped or notched edges.
  • C is for Color. Multiple colors are a warning sign.
  • D is for Diameter: if the size of the lesion is 6 mm or larger.
  • E is for Evolving. Any change in size, shape, color or elevation, or any new symptom in it, such as bleeding, itching or crusting, may be a warning sign of melanoma.

Immunohistochemical markers of melanoma are - HMB45, S100 , MELAN A , LDH

Most important prognostic factor in melanoma is - LYMPH NODE STATUS

Option B- BCC typically presents as a shiny, pink- or flesh-colored papule or nodule with surface telangiectasia. The tumor may enlarge and ulcerate, giving the borders a rolled or rodent ulcer appearance.

Option C- Squamous cell carcinoma has a precursor lesion, actinic keratosis, which exhibits tumor progression. Primary risk factor is UV solar radiation.

questions.text: 10-year-old girl came in emergency with jaundice. Blood tests reveal uraemia and thrombocytopenia. A peripheral blood film demonstrates the presence of schistocytes. What is your probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a form of mechanical hemolytic anemia resulting from intravascular fragmentation and lysis of red cells due to microvascular endothelial abnormalities (like fibrin, platelet thrombi).
  • Common causes are thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), eclampsia, hemolysis elevated enzymes low platelet count (HELLP) syndrome, disseminated malignancies and generalized vasculitis. Blood film shows numerous fragmented red cells (schistocytes) and nucleated red cells.
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia-peripheral blood smear. This specimen from a patient with hemolytic uremic syndrome contains several fragmented red cells.
  1. Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS):
    • HS is a genetic disorder characterized by defects in red blood cell membrane proteins.
    • Clinical features typically include hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly.
    • While HS can lead to hemolysis and jaundice, it doesn't usually cause thrombocytopenia or the presence of schistocytes. Thrombocytopenia and schistocytes are not typical features of HS.
  2. Sickle Cell Anemia:
    • Sickle cell anemia is a genetic disorder causing abnormal hemoglobin production leading to misshapen red blood cells.
    • It primarily manifests as hemolytic anemia, jaundice, and vaso-occlusive crises.
    • Thrombocytopenia and schistocytes are not characteristic features of sickle cell anemia.
  3. Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) Deficiency:
    • G6PD deficiency is an X-linked genetic disorder affecting red blood cell function.
    • Individuals with G6PD deficiency can experience hemolysis triggered by certain medications or oxidative stressors.
    • While it can cause hemolysis and jaundice in response to specific triggers, it doesn't typically result in thrombocytopenia or the presence of schistocytes.
  • Given the clinical presentation of jaundice, uraemia, thrombocytopenia, and schistocytes on the peripheral blood film, along with the absence of other common features associated with the above conditions, the most probable diagnosis in this case is Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anemia (MAHA).
  • MAHA is a category of disorders characterized by red blood cell fragmentation due to microvascular damage, leading to the combination of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and schistocytes. Specific conditions like TTP and HUS fall under the MAHA category and can present with these features.

Reference: Robbins, 10th edition page number - 452; Essential of clinical kawthalkar, 2nd edition page number - 291

choices.text: Elastic recoil of the lungs decreases

questions.text: A sedentary individual goes to her physician's office for a cardiopulmonary exercise stress test evaluation prior to starting a weight-loss exercise regimen. Physiological changes that occur during deep inspirations as lung volume approaches total lung capacity include which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) varies with lung volume. PVR is lowest at functional residual capacity, and increases at both high and low lung volumes.
  • The increased pulmonary vascular resistance seen at total lung capacity (TLC) is due to an increase in the resistance of the alveolar vessels (pulmonary capillaries) caused by compression by the high alveolar volume.
  • The increased pulmonary vascular resistance seen at residual volume is due to an increase in the resistance of the extra-alveolar vessels caused by compression by the positive intrapleural pressure generated during a forced expiration.
  • As lung volume increases toward TLC, the compliance of the lungs (slope of pressure-volume curve) decreases and elastic recoil of the lung increases, that is, the lungs resist further expansion.
  • Intrapleural pressure becomes more sub atmospheric during inspiration, approaching -30 cm H2O at TLC; as a result, the transmural pressure across the intrathoracic airways (Pin - Pout) increases, which increases airway radius, and decreases airway resistance according to Poiseuille's law.

Reference: Ganong, pp 654-655, 658-659. Levitzky, pp 20-23, 36-37, 92-95.

questions.text: Telomere:
questions.solution:
Option A: Telomeres consist of short TG-rich repeats. Human telomeres have a variable number of repeats of the sequence 5'-TTAGGG-3', which can extend for several kilobases.

Option B: centromere connects two sister chromatids. The ends of each chromosome contain structures called telomeres.

Option C: Telomerase, a multisubunit RNA template-containing complex related to viral RNA-dependent DNA polymerases (reverse transcriptases), is the enzyme responsible for telomere synthesis and thus for maintaining the length of the telomere.

Option D: Telomere shortening has been associated with both malignant transformation and aging, so telomere and telomerase enzymes have become an attractive target for cancer chemotherapy and drug development.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 35 PN 355

questions.text: A 54 year-old man who comes with a review of his home glucose measurements shows that his PP2BS = 320 mg/dL. His current treatment regimen includes a long-acting subcutaneous insulin injection once a day. Which of the following types of insulin would be most appropriate to administer before each meal?
questions.solution:
• Given scenario of increased PP2BS even after daily long acting insulin needs administration of nutritional insulin before meal. For that monomeric insulins (eg, lispro, aspart, and glulisine) can significantly improve postprandial insulin therapy. Their onset of action is under 15 minutes and peaks at 60 minutes, a pattern that closely mimics the endogenous postprandial insulin response of normal individuals.
  • Option A : While, the peak effect of regular insulin occurs after the postprandial peak in blood glucose concentration. This mismatch between the insulin and glucose peaks generally leads to inadequate control of glucose following meals.
  • Option B & D are basal insulin, while patient is already on basal insulin, 2nd basal dose is unwarranted.
    • BBR = Basal-bolus insulin regimen = Basal insulin: administer as long-acting insulin (e.g., glargine) at bedtime. Nutritional insulin: administer as rapid-acting insulin (e.g., lispro) in equally divided doses before meals
    • SSR = Sliding scale insulin regimen = Administered as short-acting insulin before each meal and at bedtime as per scale.
    • BOT = Basal supported oral therapy = long-acting insulin injection (e.g., glargine) before bedtime combined with an oral antidiabetic drug regimen

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition By Bertram G. Katzung Pg no. 752-755

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoes surgery for a mitral valve replacement. Five days later, he develops non-blanching, darkened and purpuric lesions on his trunk and arms. Laboratory studies show WBC is 11,000/ ml, Hb is 14 mg/dL, and platelets are 70,000/ml. Administration of which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient was most likely given heparin. The complication described here is known as heparin induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).
  • It is caused by an IgG autoantibody that reacts with platelet factor 4 (PF4) on the platelet surface and forms an irreversible complex with heparin, which activates platelets leading to thrombosis and thrombocytopenia.
  • Obviously, in these cases, heparin should be stopped immediately. The patient should be switched to a direct thrombin inhibitor, such as bivalirudin, argatroban or the selective factor Xa inhibitor, fondaparinux.

There are two types of HIT.

  • Type 1 is a nonimmune response to heparin and begins 1-2 days after heparin initiation and occurs in 30%. The resulting thrombocytopenia is mild to moderate; and the platelet count rarely falls below 100,000/ml.
  • Type 2 is immune-mediated and commonly known as heparin-induced thrombocytopenia and thrombosis (HITT). It is an uncommon but potential complication in patients receiving heparin intraoperatively. ITT is characterized by thrombocytopenia, thrombosis, and thromboembolic complications, including skin necrosis and gangrene. It typically occurs 4-14 days after initiation of heparin administration.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Fourteenth Edition By Bertram G. Katzung Pg no. 834-33

questions.text: The type of epithelium as shown in the image below is present in
questions.solution:
• The type of epithelium shown in the image is the transitional epithelium and it is present in the urinary bladder.
  • Transitional epithelium is a specialized epithelium lining most of the urinary tract, hence it is also called the urothelium.
  • The deepest layer consists of columnar or cuboidal cells, and the middle layer consists of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells. The surface layer consists of large, polypoid, dome-shaped, or umbrella-shaped cells.
  • As the epithelium gets stretched to accommodate urine, the surface cells become flattened.
  • The cells are called transitional due to this apparent change (transition) from stratified cuboidal epithelium in a relaxed state to stratified squamous epithelium when it is stretched.

Reference: Textbook of Netter's Essential Histology, 2nd Edition, Urinary System, Page number - 381

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student comes to the physician because her roommates are worried about her eating. She tells the physician that she regularly eats large amounts of food(more than 10,000 calories on occasion) and then has to 'punish herself' and 'get rid of it'. She explains that she does this by sticking her finger down her throat, which causes her to vomit. She tried to hide this activity from her roommates, but on more than one occasion they have heard her retching in the bathroom. The patient is 5'5" tall and weighs 132 lb. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This college student has the classic symptoms of bulimia, in which she eats huge amounts of food (bingeing) and then feels the need to "get rid of it" (purging)
  • Her body mass index (BMI) is within a normal range and therefore anorexia is ruled out.
  • Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder is more commonly found in children, and at any rate, this woman's food intake is anything but restrictive (OPTION B).
  • Likewise, while she does binge, she also purges, making binge-eating disorder less of a good fit than bulimia (OPTION D).
  • Pica is the eating of non-nutritional objects that are not meant to be consumed (e.g., lead paint chips).
  • There is no history of this given in the vignette.

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, Eleventh edition, Chapter 15.2, Bulimia Nervosa, Page no. 517.

questions.text: Which of the following is a high energy compound?
questions.solution:
Option B: High energy compounds are those which contain energy rich bond. They are present in all living cells, participating in the energy accumulation and conversion processes.

They include,

  1. ATP (Adenosine tri phosphate)
  2. Acyl carrier protein (Option B)
  3. S - adenosylmethionine (active methionine),
  4. Thiol esters involving coenzyme A (eg, acetyl- CoA),
  5. Amino acid esters involved in protein synthesis,
  6. Uridine diphosphate glucose (UDPGlc),
  7. 5-phosphoribosyl- 1-pyrophosphate (PRPP).

Option A: Fatty acids are not considered as high energy compounds as it does not contain energy rich bonds. But they can produce energy by their breakdown (beta oxidation). One molecule of Palmitic acid (16C, saturated fatty acid) when complete breakdown (by beta oxidation & electron transport chain), it will produce net 106 ATPs. Similarly, one molecule of Stearic acid (18C, saturated fatty acid) will produce net 120 ATPs.

Option C: Glucose is not considered as high energy compounds as it does not contain energy rich bonds. Glucose can produce energy by its breakdown. One molecule of glucose (6C, aldo hexose) when complete breakdown into 6 CO2 (by glycolysis, TCA cycle & electron transport chain), it will produce net 32 ATPs.

Option D: Glycerol is also not a high energy compound.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 32nd edition CH 11 PN 108

questions.text: A 24-year-old married housewife attempted to slash her wrist after a fight with her husband over his drinking habit. The cut was made superficially on the wrist with a knife. On asking her, she later replied that she had no intent to die, but felt very angry after the fight. This is termed as:
questions.solution:
• Deliberate self-harm means wilful self-inflicting of painful, destructive, or injurious acts without intent to die (OPTION A)
  • Parasuicide is a term used to describe patients who injure themselves by self-mutilation (e.g., cutting the skin), but who usually do not wish to die. (OPTION B)
    • Hence, in the above clinical scenario, since intention to die is absent, the self-harming behaviour by cutting skin superficially is suggestive of deliberate self-harm/ Para-suicide. (CORRECT OPTION D)

questions.text: According to Durkheim, all the following are types of suicide except:
questions.solution:
Types of Suicide: Emile Durkheim classified different types of suicides on the basis of different types of relationship between the actor and his society.

  1. Egoistic suicide: when a man becomes socially isolated or feels that he has no place in the society he destroys himself. This is the suicide of self-centered person who lacks altruistic feelings and is usually cut off from mainstream of the society.
  2. Altruistic suicide: This type of suicide occurs when individuals and the group are too close and intimate. This kind of suicide results from the over integration of the individual into social proof, for example - Sati customs, Dannies warriors.
  3. Anomic suicide: This type of suicide is due to certain breakdown of social equilibrium, such as, suicide after bankruptcy or after winning a lottery. In other words, anomic suicide takes place in a situation which has cropped up suddenly.
  4. Fatalistic suicide: This type of suicide is due to overregulation in society. Under the overregulation of a society, when a servant or slave commits suicide, when a barren woman commits suicide, it is the example of fatalistic suicide

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page Number-766.

questions.text: A surgeon needs to construct a bypass between the veins of the portal and caval systems to circumvent insufficient drainage through the natural portacaval anastomoses. Which plan is likely to be successful?
questions.solution:
• The splenic vein is a major vein of the portal system, while the left renal vein is a major vein of the caval system.

  • The coronary vein, right gastroepiploic vein, inferior mesenteric vein, splenic vein, left colic vein, middle colic vein, and superior mesenteric vein are all part of the portal system.

questions.text: A 58 years old shivang complaints of chronic cough, hoarseness of voice and classic pleural effusion. On examination, a small mass was found at periphery and then histomorphology is as given below. What is the probable type of lung tumour?
questions.solution:
• Adenocarcinomas are usually peripherally located, but also may occur closer to the hilum. In general, adenocarcinomas grow slowly and form smaller masses than do the other subtypes, but they tend to metastasize widely at an early stage.
  • They may assume a variety of growth patterns, including acinar (gland-forming); papillary; mucinous which is often multifocal and may manifest as pneumonia-like consolidation); and solid types. The solid variant often requires demonstration of intracellular mucin by special stains to establish its adenocarcinomatous differentiation
  • Option b) Adenocarcinoma in situ (AIS) (formerly bronchioloalveolar carcinoma), often involves peripheral parts of the lung as a single nodule. The key features of AIS are diameter of 3 cm or less, growth along preexisting structures, and preservation of alveolar architecture.
  • Option c) Squamous cell carcinomas are more common in men than in women and are closely correlated with a smoking history; they tend to arise centrally in major bronchi and eventually spread to local hilar nodes, but they disseminate outside the thorax later than do other histologic types. Large lesions may undergo central necrosis, giving rise to cavitation.
  • Option d) Large cell carcinomas are undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumors that lack the cytologic features of neuroendocrine carcinoma and show no evidence of glandular or squamous differentiation. The cells typically have large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and moderate amounts of cytoplasm.

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-539

questions.text: A 60 year old man with chronic renal failure presents with back pain. His X-ray is shown below. What is the characteristic finding seen in the x ray?
questions.solution:
• RUGGER JERSEY SPINE is seen in RENAL OSTEODYSTROPHY
    • Renal osteodystrophy is characterized by bone mineralization deficiency due to the electrolyte and endocrine abnormalities associated with chronic kidney disease.
    • The pathogenesis of renal osteodystrophy is multifactorial.
    • Hypocalcemia occurs due to the inability of the damaged kidney to convert vitamin D3 into its active form, calcitriol.
    • The hypocalcemia and lack of phosphate excretion by the damaged kidney causes hyperparathyroidism and secondary hyperphosphatemia.
  • DDs of rugger jersey spine are given below.

Reference: Maheshwari, Essential Ortho, 4th edition, Page no. 315.

questions.text: If the musculocutaneous nerve is severed at its origin from the brachial plexus, flexion at the elbow is greatly weakened but not abolished. What muscle remains operative and can contribute to flexion?
questions.solution:
• Brachioradialis is a muscle innervated by the radial nerve it flexes the elbow and assists in pronating and supinating the arm.
  • Brachialis, coracobrachialis, and both heads of biceps brachii are all muscles which flex the arm and/or forearm, but they are all innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve.
  • These muscles would be denervated if the musculocutaneous nerve was severed at its origin from the brachial plexus.

Reference: Textbook of Gray's Anatomy for students, 3rd Edition, Upper Limb Page number - 747

choices.text: Around the growth plate in children
Cancellous bone of femur in adults

questions.text: Woven bone is found in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Woven bone is immature bone seen during embryonic development. Woven bone is weak and is slowly replaced by stronger lamellar bone during development. Woven bone is almost completely replaced by 2 years of age.

However, there are conditions where woven bone can be seen even after 2 years of age:

  1. Around growth plates in growing children
  2. During fracture healing
  3. Pathologies of bone:
    • Paget's disease
    • Fibrous dysplasia
    • Osteogenic tumours like Osteosarcoma, Osteoblastoma etc

Reference: Miller's 8th edition of Review of Orthopaedics, Page no. 20

choices.text: Expansion of air-filled spaces in the body

questions.text: All the following are seen with Nitrous oxide except:
questions.solution:
• N2O exhibits the following two effects
  • The 'concentration effect' implies that the greater the inspired anaesthetic concentration, the more rapid the rise in the alveolar concentration
  • The 'second gas effect' refers to the ability of one gas administered in a high concentration (e.g. N2O) to accelerate the uptake of another gas (e.g. halothane) that is co-administered
  • sixty-six percent of N2O in oxygen decreases the MAC of halothane to 0.29, of enflurane to 0.6, of isoflurane to 0.5, of sevoflurane to 0.66, and of desflurane to 2.8

Option A: Nitrous oxide is 35 times more soluble than nitrogen in the blood. Because of this physical property of the gas, when N2O is discontinued, the ingress of the gas into the alveoli lowers the alveolar oxygen concentration. This is called fink effect or diffusion hypoxia.

Option B: Nitrous oxide is 35 times more soluble than nitrogen in the blood; N2O will therefore cause an increase in the size of air-filled spaces (e.g. pneumothorax, intestines, air cysts in the middle ear) in the body.

Option D: 15% of patients receiving N2O will experience nausea and vomiting.

Reference: Drugs in Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, Edward Scarth, Susan Smith 5th edition pg. 278.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of abdominal discomfort. Physical examination demonstrates splenomegaly but no lymphadenopathy. A CBC shows pancytopenia. Examination of a peripheral blood smear reveals atypical lymphoid cells that exhibit tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase activity. Which of the following is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Adult males. Mature B-cell tumor. Cells have filamentous, hairlike projections (fuzzy appearing on light microscopy). Peripheral lymphadenopathy is uncommon.
  • Causes marrow fibrosis -> dry tap on aspiration. Patients usually present with massive splenomegaly and pancytopenia.
  • Stains TRAP (Tartrate-Resistant Acid Phosphatase) ⊕ (TRAPped in a hairy situation). TRAP stain largely replaced with flow cytometry. Associated with BRAF mutations.

Treatment: purine analogs (cladribine, pentostatin).

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Diseases 10th edition Chapter 13, pg 603 - 605

questions.text: The inhalational agent of choice for asthmatics?
questions.solution:
• Sevoflurane is the agent of choice for asthmatics because of its bronchodilation
  • Though halothane also produces equal bronchodilation, Sevoflurane appears to have a greater therapeutic index than halothane
    • Halothane sensitizes the heart to adrenaline and causes Cardiovascular depression, Bradycardia, Arrhythmias, Respiratory depression which are less likely with sevoflurane
  • Isoflurane and Desflurane can provide equal bronchodilation but are not normally used for inhalation induction (Option C)
  • Desflurane is not used because of its pungency which may result in Cough, Laryngospasm, Bronchospasm

Reference: Drugs in Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, Edward Scarth, Susan Smith 5th edition

questions.text: A medical student goes for a swim while on vacation in Florida after final exams. A barracuda bites his foot, severing an artery on the dorsum of his foot just below his ankle. Which artery has been severed?
questions.solution:
• The dorsalis pedis is a continuation of the anterior tibial artery.
  • Since the artery on the dorsum of the foot was cut just below the ankle, dorsalis pedis must have been the vessel that was injured.
  • The deep plantar artery is a branch of dorsalis pedis. it supplies the deep foot, and reaches this area by passing through a space between the first and second metatarsals on the dorsum of the foot.
  • The dorsal metatarsal arteries are small arteries that come off of the arcuate artery and travel to the individual digits.
  • They supply the dorsum of digits, excluding the distal phalangeal segment.

Reference: Textbook of Gray's Anatomy for students, 3rd Edition, Lower Limb, Page number: 623

questions.text: Figure shows the pin index safety system in cylinders. Match the index to the correct gas from the table.
questions.solution:
• The pin-index system is a safety feature, designed to prevent wrong connection of a cylinder containing one substance to a delivery system of different substance
  • For example, attaching a nitrous oxide cylinder to the oxygen delivery system would produce 100% N2O, while you may believe you are attempting to give 100% O2. This will cause lethal damage to the patient. To prevent such accidents, PISS (pin-index safety system) was introduced
  • The system works by having a series of holes drilled into the valve on top of the cylinder in particular positions for each gas - these correspond to pins on the anesthesia machine, which prevent connection unless the pins fit into the respective holes.

Reference: OSCE's in Anaesthesia (William Simpson) pg. 110

choices.text: Vineet recorded the increase in MBP but Kamlesh recorded a decrease in MBP
Vineet recorded a decrease in MBP but Kamlesh recorded an increase in MBP
Both recorded an increase in MBP
Both recorded a decrease in MBP

questions.text: Two students, Vineet and Kamlesh were asked to demonstrate in dogs the role of sinus nerve in hypovolemic shock. Vineet severed the sinus nerve when the mean blood pressure (MBP) was 85 mm Hg and Kamlesh cut the sinus nerve when the mean blood pressure was 60 mm Hg. On cutting the sinus nerve
questions.solution:
• Baroreceptors don't fire below 60 mm Hg, Maximum rate of firing is seen around 180 mm Hg
  • baroreceptors are ineffective in BP control whenever MAP falls below 60 mm Hg and chemoreceptors are effective below 60 mm Hg
  • Afferent impulses from both carotid sinus (baroreceptor) and carotid body (chemoreceptor) travel through the same sinus nerve (Hering's nerve)
  • Between 60 mm Hg to 180 mm Hg, baroreceptors fire to inhibit sympathetic activity in medulla
  • Below 60 mm Hg, chemoreceptors fire to cause chemoreflex which is- stimulation of vasomotor center leading to:
    • Vasoconstriction
    • Tachycardia
    • Increase in BP
  • baroreceptors fire to inhibit sympathetic activity in medulla and chemoreceptors fire to increase sympathetic activity in medulla
  • Now, coming to the question, Vineet severed the sinus nerve at MBP 85 mm Hg. At this pressure of 85 mm Hg, normally baroreceptors send their discharge through sinus nerve to inhibit sympathetic activity in medulla
  • If the sinus nerve is cut at 85 mm Hg, baroreceptors can no longer inhibit sympathetic activity in medulla. So, sympathetic activity in medulla increases - there is increase in BP. Vineet recorded the increase in MBP
  • Kamlesh severed the sinus nerve at MBP 60 mm Hg. We know that below 60 mm Hg chemoreceptors fire and the impulse is carried through the same sinus nerve to medulla to increase sympathetic activity. Kamlesh severed the sinus nerve at MBP 60 mm Hg-recorded a decrease in MBP (chemoreceptor activity is not conveyed to medulla no sympathetic activity decrease in MBP)

Reference: Ganong, 25th edition page no.590

questions.text: What is the most useful investigation in patient suspected to develop traumatic aortic dissection?
questions.solution:
• Chest CT angiography (CTA) is essential in the diagnosis of acute aortic syndromes. Acute aortic syndromes have high morbidity and mortality, particularly when involving the ascending aorta, and include classic aortic dissection, penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer, and acute intramural hematoma.
  • An understanding of the pathogenesis and distinguishing imaging features of acute aortic syndromes and aortic rupture and some less common manifestations is helpful when interpreting imaging examinations.
  • Related entities, such as ulcerated plaque, ulcer like projections, and intramural blood pools, and mimics, such as vasculitis and aortic thrombus, are important to recognize; knowledge of these is important to avoid interpretive pitfalls.
  • In addition, an awareness of postsurgical aortic changes can be useful when interpreting CTA examinations when patient history is incomplete.

Reference: Chest CT Angiography for Acute Aortic Pathologic Conditions: Pearls and Pitfalls

Jane P. Ko, Jonathan M. Goldstein, Larry A. Latson, Jr, Lea Azour, Elliott K. Gozansky, William Moore, Smita Patel, and Barry Hutchinson

Radio Graphics 2021 41:2, 399-424

questions.text: Proteins are linear polymers of amino acids. They fold into compact structures. Sometimes, these folded structures associate to form homo-or- heterodimers. Which one of the following refers to this associated form?
questions.solution:
Primary Structure is the linear sequence of amino acids held together by peptide bonds in its peptide chains. Bond involved in primary structure is Peptide Bond, a type of covalent bond.

Secondary Structure

  • Configurational relationship between residues which are about 3-4 amino Acids apart in linear sequence.
  • The folding of short (3- to 30- residue), contiguous segments of polypeptide into geometrically ordered units
  • Bonds involved in the secondary structure are primarily noncovalent bonds like:
    • Hydrogen Bond (Most important Bond)
    • Hydrophobic Bond
    • Electrostatic Bond (Ionic Bond, Salt Bridges)
    • van der Waals forces.

Tertiary structure: The entire three-dimensional conformation of a polypeptide is referred to as tertiary structure. Quaternary structure: If more than one polypeptide aggregates to form one functional protein, the spatial relationship between the polypeptide subunits is referred to as quaternary structure.

Bonds involved in Tertiary and Quaternary Structures are primarily noncovalent bonds.

  • Hydrophobic Interaction
  • Hydrogen Bond
  • Electrostatic Bond
  • Van der Waal's Forces

Some covalent bonds may be present, like disulphide bonds (both intra- & inter-strand) and cross links between side chains of strands

Reference: Harper's 32nd edition, page 39

questions.text: Which of the following is seen on CXR in COVID 19 patients?
questions.solution:
• Findings of COVID-19 on chest radiographs vary, ranging from normal in the early stages of disease to unilateral or bilateral lung opacities, sometimes with a basilar and strikingly peripheral distribution.
  • Early research reported a relatively low sensitivity (69%) for the diagnosis of COVID-19 using baseline chest radiography.
  • Although underlying comorbidities such as chronic lung disease or congestive heart failure may confound chest radiograph interpretation, studies have shown that many of the hallmark chest CT findings are apparent on chest radiograph

Reference: COVID-19 Imaging: What We Know Now and What Remains Unknown Jeffrey P. Kanne, Harrison Bai, Adam Bernheim, Michael Chung, Linda B. Haramati, David F. Kallmes, Brent P. Little, Geoffrey Rubin, and Nicola Sverzellati Radiology 2021 299:3, E262-E279

questions.solution: Reference: Wintrobes 12th edition pg 702

questions.text: A medical student was asked by her preceptor to palpate the margin of the superficial inguinal ring of a healthy male patient. After passing her finger down the edge of the medial crus of the superficial inguinal ring, she felt a bony protuberance deep to the lateral edge of the spermatic cord, which she correctly identified as the :
questions.solution:
• The pubic tubercle is a bony process that would be felt lateral to the edge of the spermatic cord at the superficial inguinal ring. (This is really the only answer choice that could feel like a bony prominence when palpated).
  • The pubic tubercle serves as the point of attachment for the inguinal ligament, which makes up the floor of the inguinal canal.
  • The pubic pecten is the ridge on the superior surface of the superior pubic ramus. This is the place where you find the pectineal ligament, a thickening of fascia on the pecten of the pubis.
  • The pectineal ligament is a good place to put sutures when doing surgery. The pubic symphysis is the joint between the two pubic bones.
  • The iliopubic eminence is a bony process on the pubis found near its articulation with the ilium. The iliopectineal line is a line formed by the arcuate line of the ilium and the pectineal line of the pubis.
  • This line forms a plane that marks the transition between the abdominal and pelvic cavity.

Reference: Textbook of Gray's Anatomy for students, 3rd Edition, Abdomen, Page number - 146

choices.text: Acute inflammation of the vessel wall
Bacterial colonies in the vessel wall
Lipid deposition and smooth muscle cell hyperplasia

questions.text: A 65-year-old man having a familial history of diabetes. He was diagnosed as diabetic 6 years back, and having uncontrolled sugar level along with systemic hypertension suddenly dies of congestive heart failure. The luminal surface of the abdominal aorta is shown in the image. Which of the following pathologic changes would you expect to see on microscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Atherosclerosis is a disease of large and medium-sized elastic and muscular arteries that result in the progressive accumulation within the intima of inflammatory cells, hyperplastic smooth muscle cells, lipids, and connective tissue. The resulting characteristic lesion, the lipid plaque (atheroma), contains pools of extracellular lipid and numerous lipid-laden macrophages (foam cells).

(a) It is not an acute inflammatory condition.

(b & c) It is not an acute infectious process related change.

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed, pg 499

questions.text: Which of the following condition can lead to the production of the image shown in the below image
questions.solution:
• The Ct scan image shows intramural air (air within the bowel wall) called pneumatosis intestinalis
  • Acute mesenteric ischemia is caused by mesenteric arterial or venous narrowing or occlusion, causing inadequate perfusion of the bowel. The majority of cases are related to arterial occlusion with embolic (atrial fibrillation, endocarditis) and atherosclerotic events being the most common cause.
  • Suggestive CT findings include clot within the superior mesenteric artery, the superior mesenteric vein or mesenteric vessels, diminished or absent mural enhancement
  • Pneumatosis intestinalis is a late and commonly irreversible finding in ischemia, suggestive of infarction.

Reference: Gastrointestinal Imaging Cases, Angela D. Levy, Koenraad J. Mortele, and Benjamin M. Yeh; page number 106

questions.text: Which of the following heart sound may be a normal finding during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Rapid filling phase
  • Opening of AV valves leads to rapid filling of ventricles
  • This rapid inflow of blood vibrates ventricular walls and causes third heart sound (S₃)
  • S₃ is normally heard in children, pregnancy

Reference: Ganong, 25th edition / page no. 540

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with intermittent pain and stiffness in her hands and feet. She takes ibuprofen for the pain, which provides good relief. She had her last attack 7 days ago. An X-ray of her hands is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
• This patient presents with a history of joint pain in > 2 small and medium size joints. The x-ray shows joint surface destruction and narrowed joint spaces of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints. In addition, the distal interphalangeal joints are spared, which is typical for rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Methotrexate is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) and the first-line, long-term therapy for moderate-to-severe rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Early administration of DMARDs is crucial, because damage to the affected joints occurs early in the course of RA. Methotrexate is highly effective, well-tolerated, and inexpensive but has a slow onset of action (> 6 weeks).

For this reason, bridging therapy with glucocorticoids or NSAIDs is normally indicated during acute attacks, but this patient's last acute attack has already ended 7 days ago, obviating the need for bridging therapy.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology by Bertram G. Katzung, 14th Edition, Page Number 987-990.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis 2 months back returns to the office reporting blurring of vision. The patient is on combination therapy with isoniazid, ethambutol, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and pyridoxine. Examination shows bilateral central scotomas. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's visual symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Pulmonary TB is treated with a 4-drug regimen, sometimes referred to as RIPE: rifampin, isoniazid (INH), pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.
  • The most notable side effect of ethambutol is optic neuropathy, which clinically manifests as decreased visual acuity, central scotoma, or color blindness. It may be reversible with discontinuation of the drug.

REFERENCE: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition By Bertram G. Katzung Page no. 843

Permanent erasure of the name of the RMP from the medical register

questions.text: The term 'Professional Death Sentence' denotes-
questions.solution:
• The disciplinary action taken by the medical council against a doctor may be a warning or penal erasure (removal of the name of the medical practitioner from the medical register).
  • Penal erasure may be temporary or permanent.
  • In case of serious and gross medical negligence, the name of the medical practitioner is removed permanently, known as professional death sentence.
  • Rigorous imprisonment and the death penalty can be passed only by the court of law.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page Number-20.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to cause CKD?
questions.solution:
All the other conditions cause acute renal failure.

Berger's disease(IgA nephropathy) is associated with chronic renal failure in up to 30% of adult cases. It is the commonest glomerular disease worldwide. It usually follows a viral upper respiratory tract infection. Heavy proteinuria, renal failure and hypertension indicate a poor prognosis.

Option A: Leptospirosis, also called Weil's disease, is spread by contact with infected rat urine. Features include meningitis, myocarditis, acute renal failure and haemolytic anemia.

Option B: Haemolytic uraemic syndrome is associated with acute damage and occlusion of small blood vessels(arterioles and capillaries) in the kidney. Thrombotic microangiopathy associated with Escherichia coli infection(especially O157 serotypes) is now the most common cause of acute renal failure in children in developed countries.

Option C: Vancomycin is a bactericidal antibiotic. Indications are limited to serious infections such as endocarditis and septicaemia. It is nephrotoxic and can precipitate acute renal failure.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal medicine, 21st edition, Ch:314, Pg:2339.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a history of progressive difficulty in climbing stairs and rising from chairs. She also complains of difficulty in swallowing. She complains that her hands discolour and become cold easily. On examination she has purple discoloration of her eyelids and periorbital oedema. There is weakness of the muscles of her limb girdles. What is the likely cause of the dysphagia?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is dermatomyositis.

Characteristic features of DM:

  • Symmetric, proximal greater than distal weakness
  • Heliotrope rash (erythematous discoloration of eyelids with periorbital edema)
  • Gottron sign (erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles)
  • Gottron papules (raised erythematous rash over knuckles)
  • V-sign (rash on the sun-exposed anterior neck and chest)
  • Shawl sign over the back of the neck and shoulders

Dysphagia in dermatomyositis is primarily due to weakness of the striated musculature of the posterior pharynx. Dysphagia may also result from cricopharyngeal obstruction secondary to inflammation or fibrosis of the cricopharyngeal muscles.



Heliotrope rash in dermatomyositis

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Ch:365 Pg:2820
