  • Triangular obturator foramen, -shaped pubic angle, everted ischial tuberosity, large greater sciatic notch, deep preauricular sulcus are characteristics of a female pelvis.
  • The differences between male and female pelvis are summarized in the table below.


Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page No. 45. 46

questions.text: The incision preferred during autopsy in case of asphyxial death due to neck compression is
questions.solution:
• The incision preferred in the case of asphyxial death due to neck compression (as in hanging, strangulation etc.) is the Y-shaped incision.


  1. I-shaped incision: The usual incision is drawn from just below the chin to the pubic symphysis avoiding the umbilicus and any injuries in the line of incision. This is the most common method followed.
  2. Y-shaped incision: The two incisions commence on either side of the neck from 2 to 3 cm behind the lobe of each ear to meet at manubrium sterni and then continued as a single incision down to pubic symphysis avoiding the umbilicus. It is used when a detailed study of neck organs is required, such as death due to compression on the neck (hanging or strangulation) and any condition where the larynx might be damaged, as the skin of the upper neck can then be dissected off the mandible and raised clear to give a wide approach to the neck structures.
  3. Modified Y-shaped incision: Two incisions are made, commencing on either side of the chest starting from both acromia, running away and below the breasts to meet at xiphisternum and to be continued as a single vertical incision down to pubic symphysis avoiding the umbilicus. This is desirable in those cases (especially females) where it is customary to restore the body in a reasonable cosmetic condition for view for some time after death.
  4. Inverted Y- shaped incision: An incision from the symphysis menti to umbilicus, then extending to bilateral mid-inguinal point. It is used in foetus and new-born to study umbilical arteries.

References: Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 5th Edition, Kishan Vij, Page no. 20; Knight's Forensic Pathology, 4th Edition, Page N0. 19

questions.text: Which of the following diseases present mainly as Glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Glomerular diseases can present in 2 ways- Nephritic Syndrome or Nephrotic Syndrome. Clinical distinction of both is required to identify the disease process and to plan investigations.

NEPHRITIC SYNDROME:

  1. Hematuria.
  2. RBC cast.
  3. Hypertension.
  4. Proteinuria of the range 1-2g/day.
  5. Varying degrees of decline in GFR.

Diseases that present predominantly as Nephritis are: Post streptococcal Glomerulonephritis, Sub acute bacterial endocarditis, Lupus Nephritis, IgA Nephropathy, Basement Membrane Disease, ANCA associated vasculitis, Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

NEPHROTIC SYNDROME:

  1. Heavy proteinuria, >3gm/day
  2. Edema/anasarca
  3. Hypertension
  4. Hypercholesterolemia
  5. Hypoalbuminemia
  6. Hematuria, variable.

Diseases that predominantly present as Nephrotic syndrome: Minimal change disease, Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, Membranous glomerulonephritis, diabetic nephropathy, Amyloidosis, Light chain deposition disease, Fabry's Disease.

There can be overlap between these two, eg: heavy proteinuria in Glomerulonephritis, known as Nephritic-nephrotic Syndrome.

Reference: Harrison's principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 314, Pg: 2334.

questions.text: A patient is presented with rashes all over the body sparing palm and soles. There is no history of animal exposure in this patient. Which of the following bacterial species is most likely the causative agent?

questions.text: The following postmortem finding is noted on a dead body. This finding is most prominent after how many hours of death?
questions.solution:
• The given picture shows postmortem marbling. It starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.
  • Marbling is the staining of the walls of the superficial veins by sulf methemoglobin(Initially red, then greenish)
  • Seen most clearly on the thighs, sides of the abdomen and chest & shoulders
  • The blood in the vessels is haemolysed, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page No. 121, 122

questions.text: A 36-year-old male, Rahul, presented with severe fever, impaired awareness, headache and seizures. Neck rigidity was not seen. CSF PCR was conducted which was positive for HSV1. Which lobe is commonly affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
• Fever, impaired awareness, headache and seizures without nuchal rigidity and PCR positive for HSV is suggestive of Herpes Encephalitis.
  • Herpes is the most common cause of sporadic encephalitis, and it commonly affects Temporal lobe in adults.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 550

questions.text: A 45-year-old male has a history of 6 months of cutaneous symptoms in the form of Raynaud's Phenomenon and livedo reticularis. He recently has history of numbness of the hands and feet. He presents to the emergency department with testicular pain. Which of the following complications is he least likely to develop?
questions.solution:
The patient in this question has a vasculitis as evidenced by the presence of involvement of multiple symptoms. The catch in the question is the presence of testicular pain, which is seen in Polyarteritis Nodosa.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium vessel vasculitis which is characterized by the absence of pulmonary involvement and glomerulonephritis. Microscopy shows transmural fibrinoid necrosis without granulomas.

Renal impairment can occur due to involvement of branches of renal artery.

Mesenteric ischemia and bowel infarction can also occur. Hepatic infarction can also occur. Dermatological manifestations are Raynaud's Phenomenon, livedo reticularis, nodules, rash, purpura etc.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 363, Pg 2811

questions.solution:
1. Catch up- immunise all children between the ages of 9 months to 10 years irrespective of their previous immunisation status
  2. Keep up- continue the ongoing national immunisation program
  3. Follow up- done every 2-4 years to vaccinate all >9 months of age, who have been born after the last Catch up campaign


Other Options:

a. 90-90-90- For AIDS: 90% of HIV-infected individuals to be diagnosed by 2020, 90% of whom will be on anti-retroviral therapy (ART) and 90% of whom will achieve sustained virologic suppression.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd Edition, Page Number 562

questions.text: A 20 year old female comes with history of arthritis, butterfly rash and fever of one month duration. Up on testing, her ANA is positive with positive anti ds DNA and Anti histone antibody. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This question deals with the different types of auto antibodies associated with SLE and their clinical significance.

Antibodies in SLE:

ANA is highly sensitive test for SLE but is very nonspecific. Positive in 98% of patients with SLE.

Immunofluorescence (IF) is the gold standard technique for detecting ANA. Several Antinuclear antibodies have been identified based on the pattern of fluorescence in IF.



Seeing this question, we may tend to answer it as Drug induced lupus since she has anti histone antibodies.

Anti histone antibody is seen in drug induced lupus, but it is not specific for it. Anti ds DNA is specific for SLE. Hence drug induced lupus will be negative for ds DNA. Anti histone antibodies will be seen in 70% of SLE. So, the answer is SLE.

Anti Ribosomal P antibody is seen in Neuropsychiatric lupus.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed Ch: 356, Pg: 2738

questions.text: Which of the following is Fungi imperfecti
questions.solution:
• Taxonomical Classification -
  • Based on the production of sexual spores, the Kingdom Fungi has been divided into four medically important phyla. They are as follows:
    • Phylum zygomycota: They are lower fungi, produce sexual spores known as zygospores and possess aseptate hyphae, e.g. Rhizopus and Mucor
    • Phylum ascomycota: They produce sexual spores known as ascospores and possess septate hyphae, e.g. Aspergillus
    • Phylum basidiomycota: They produce sexual spores known as basidiospore e.g. Cryptococcus
    • Phylum deuteromycota (Fungi imperfecti): In majority of the medically important fungi, the sexual state is either absent or unidentified yet. Hence, they are traditionally grouped as fungi imperfecti.

Reference : Sastry 3rd ed pg. 116

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg no. 87

questions.text: A 32 year old lady has altered bowel habit. At the gastroenterology clinic, her symptoms are reviewed. She has a 2 year history of bloating and abdominal pains which get better after defecation. Some weeks she is constipated and during others she has diarrhoea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

IBS is a functional bowel disorder occurring in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities.



Weight loss, fevers and blood in the stool are features which suggest a different organic cause other than irritable bowel syndrome.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Ed, Ch: 327 pg: 2490

questions.text: A Covid 19 patient with uncontrolled diabetes develops significant visual impairment. Which of the following is the line of management
questions.solution:
• Rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. Pulmonary mucormycosis is the second most common form.
  • Mucormycosis is an invasive disease caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia.
  • The disease is often characterized by hyphae growing in and around the blood vessels. It can turn fatal on cerebral involvement and development of septicaemia.

Risk factors for the infection include:

  • Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Elevated levels of free iron.
  • Defects in phagocytic function. (e.g. neutropenia or steroid therapy).
  • Organ or hematopoietic stem transplantation.
  • End stage renal disease
  • Patients taking iron therapy or deferoxamine (iron chelator)
  • Treatment of choice is Amphotericin-B. Posaconazole can be used as an alternative drug.

Reference:

  • Ananthanarayan and paniker's microbiology; 10th edition Page no: 615
  • Sastry 3rd edition pg. 680.
  • Ananthanarayan and Paniker's textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg no.409-410

questions.text: A 44-year-old man has a 5-year history of bloody diarrhea mixed with mucus. He had lost 2 stones in weight over this time. Flexible sigmoidoscopy showed loss of vascular appearance, erythema, and superficial ulceration consistent with ulcerative colitis. Which one of the following features is associated with the condition?
questions.solution:
The extraintestinal manifestations of Inflammatory Bowel Disease include-

  • Ocular - Episcleritis, uveitis
  • Rheumatological - Ankylosing spondylitis, peripheral migratory arthritis
  • Dermatological - Erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis - most common in ulcerative colitis
  • Nephrolithiasis (calcium oxalate stones - most common)- most common in Crohn’s disease (CD)

Terminal ileum is the most commonly involved site in CD. Megaloblastic anemia occurs in CD as vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Ed, Ch: 326, Pg: 2480-2482

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman with COPD develops diarrheoa of 1-week duration. She says that she took enough fluids 'to keep up with diarrhea', but abdominal cramps and slight dizziness brought her to the ED. She is alert and oriented. Her BP is 120/60 mmHg with a heart rate of 96 beats/min. Respiratory rate is 19/min. She has orthostatic BP and pulse changes. Laboratory values:

What is the acid-base disturbance?
questions.solution:
• Low pH, high pCO2, and HCO3 indicate that the primary acid-base disorder is chronic respiratory acidosis. If she had acute respiratory acidosis, her serum HCO3 would have been 26 (24 + 2) rather than 28 mEq/L.
  • Since she is a known case of COPD with an elevated pCO2 she is expected to have a chronic metabolic alkalosis; her expected HCO3- would be 24+(0.4*22) = 32.8 mmol/L
  • The pH and serum [HCO3] are low for chronic respiratory acidosis.
  • Since she has diarrhoea, she developed non-AG metabolic acidosis, which lowered HCO3 and pH. Note that pCO2 may have been slightly lowered because of a mild increase in respiratory rate.
  • Thus, the patient has chronic respiratory acidosis and metabolic acidosis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Ed, Ch:55 Pg: 359

questions.text: BPaL regimen is
questions.solution:
• FDA approved the use of pretomanid 200 mg in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid (BPaL) in August 2019. CDC recommends the use of pretomanid 200 mg daily for 26 weeks in the treatment of adults with pulmonary extensively drug-resistant (XDR), pre-extensively drug-resistant (pre-XDR) (i.e., resistant to isoniazid, rifampin, and at least one fluoroquinolone or injectable medications (i.e., amikacin, kanamycin, capreomycin)) or treatment-intolerant (TI)/nonresponsive (NR) multidrug-resistant TB when a safe and effective treatment regimen cannot otherwise be provided and when administered in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid as the BPaL regimen.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Ed, Ch: 178 Pg: 1377

questions.text: A 22 year old man is well but jaundiced. His urine color is normal. His liver function tests show total bilirubin 3.2 mg/dl; unconjugated bilirubin: 2.8 mg/dL, ALT 26 U/l, AST 25 U/l, GGT 40 U/l and ALP 80 U/l. CBC is unremarkable. Ultrasound scan of abdomen shows normal parenchymal texture of the liver. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
The case describes a young patient with isolated jaundice and labs suggestive of isolated unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The differentials of this patient include:

  • Inherited disorders: Crigler Najjar Syndrome, Gilbert's syndrome
  • Drugs: Rifampicin, probenecid
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis (Eg. B12, Folate deficiency)
  • Hemolytic disorders

Since CBC is unremarkable, B12 deficiency is ruled out.

Dubin Johnson syndrome is a disorder causing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Gilbert's syndrome is also marked by the impaired conjugation of bilirubin due to reduced bilirubin UDPGT activity (typically 10-35% of normal). Patients with Gilbert's syndrome have mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, with serum levels almost always <6 mg/dL. The serum levels may fluctuate, and jaundice is often identified only during periods of stress, concurrent illness, alcohol use, or fasting. Unlike both Crigler-Najjar syndromes, Gilbert's syndrome is very common.

Crigler-Najjar type Iis an exceptionally rare condition found in neonates and characterized by severe jaundice (bilirubin>20 mg/dL) and neurologic impairment due to kernicterus, frequently leading to death in infancy or childhood. These patients have a complete absence of bilirubin UDPGT activity; are totally unable to conjugate bilirubin; and hence cannot excrete it.

Crigler-Najjar type IIis somewhat more common than type I. Patients live into adulthood with serum bilirubin levels: 6-25 mg/dL. In these patients, mutations in the bilirubin UDPGT gene cause the reduction-typically ≤10%-of the enzyme's activity. Bilirubin UDPGT activity can be induced by the administration of phenobarbital, which can reduce serum bilirubin levels in these patients. Despite marked jaundice, these patients usually survive into adulthood, although they may be susceptible to kernicterus under the stress of concurrent illness or surgery.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Ch:338 Pg:2559; chap 49 pg 317, 318

questions.text: All of the following can be seen in refeeding syndrome except:
questions.solution:
This is characterized by shift in fluid and electrolyte shift in malnourished patients undergoing refeeding. It is more common with parenteral fluids.It results in hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 25, Edition: 28th, Pg: 338

questions.text: Which among the following is not a preventive technique for frey's syndrome following parotidectomy?
questions.solution:
The incidence of Frey's syndrome is minimal when extracapsular dissection is performed as the parotid fascia is primarily repaired and communication between denuded parotid parenchyma and subcutis sealed off.

  • There are a number of quite invasive techniques described to prevent Frey's syndrome following parotidectomy. These include:
  • sternomastoid muscle flap;
  • temporalis fascial flap;
  • insertion of artificial membranes between the skin and the parotid bed.

All these methods replace the barrier between the skin and the parotid bed to minimise inappropriate regeneration of autonomic nerve fibres.

MANAGEMENT OF ESTABLISHED FREY'S SYNDROME

Methods of managing Frey's syndrome include:

  • antiperspirants, usually containing aluminium chloride;
  • denervation by tympanic neurectomy;
  • the injection of botulinum toxin into the affected skin.

The last is the most effective and can be performed as an out-patient.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 54, Edition: 28th, Pg: 849

questions.text: Fat burn is which kind of burn
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 46, Edition: 28th, Pg: 669

questions.text: Diagnose condition given in below image
questions.solution:
• Left-sided diaphragmatic injury on plain chest radiograph.

The gas-filled stomach can be visualized on the left side of the chest because of herniation through a large diaphragmatic laceration.

Reference: Sabiston textbook of surgery, 21st edition, page - 411

questions.text: Which type of audiogram is seen in early stage of Meniere's disease
questions.solution:
• In Meniere's disease, there is Sensorineural Hearing Loss. In early stages, lower frequencies are affected. So, there is a rising audiogram. Later, with the progression of the disease, higher frequencies also get involved. This leads to a flat or falling audiogram.


  • Presbycusis has sloping audiogram as age causes high frequency hearing loss in early stages in both ears.
  • Dip at 4000 Hz in AC and BC curve in audiogram is suggestive of noise induced hearing loss. This is called acoustic dip. Dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve is seen in Otosclerosis (Carhart's Notch).

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page - 121.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman was brought to the hospital following a fall. Her neighbour thinks that she was on the floor for about 4 days. Her blood results show: sodium 132 mEq/l, potassium 6.5 mEq/l, urea 110 mg/dl, creatinine 7.3 mg/dl, calcium 7.6 mg/dl, phosphate 7.5 mg/dl.(Ref values: s. creatinine: 0.6-1.4 mg/dl; S. urea: 17 - 43 mg/dL; s. sodium: 135-145 mEq/L; S. potassium: 3.5-5 mEq/L; S. calcium: 8.8 - 10 mg/dl; S. phosphate: 3.0-4.5 mg/dL)Which of the following investigations is most likely to reveal the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The question deals with renal impairment, probably acute, in an elderly woman, who was found unresponsive and who is suspected to have fallen at least 4 days back. Muscle compression due to prolonged immobilization, as in this case will result in release of myoglobin. It is toxic to the renal tubules and will result in AKI.

The most likely diagnosis is rhabdomyolysis and acute renal failure. The history is suggestive along with hyperkalemia, hypocalcaemia, and hyperphosphatemia.

Serum creatine kinase and myoglobin will be elevated.

Other causes of rhabdomyolysis are:

  • Traumatic crush injuries
  • Muscle ischemia during vascular or orthopedic surgery
  • Compression during coma or immobilization
  • Prolonged seizure activity
  • Excessive exercise
  • Heat stroke
  • Malignant hyperthermia
  • Infections
  • Metabolic disorders (e.g., hypophosphatemia, severe hypothyroidism)
  • Myopathies (drug-induced, metabolic, or inflammatory).

Urine dipstick will be positive for blood (myoglobinuria) but microscopy will not show red cells. A renal biopsy may also reveal the diagnosis. Treatment is with hydration (normal saline) and alkalinisation of urine with sodium bicarbonate infusion.

Option A: Ultrasound is useful only to distinguish obstructive Etiologies and cystic kidney diseases

Option B: MRA is useful to assess for renal vascular diseases

Option C: A DMSA scan is a radionuclide scan that uses dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) in assessing renal morphology, structure and function

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Ed, Ch: 310 Pg: 2301

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria is known to cause pseudohemoptysis, as a result of its inherent characteristic to produce a non-diffusible red pigment?
questions.solution:
Serratia Marcescens is a normal soil saprophyte releasing a non-diffusing red pigment called Prodigiosin, which causes nosocomial UTI and Pneumonia. Due to its red pigment, it leads to pseudohemoptysis.



Enterobacter is a normal GI bacterium, known to cause nosocomial infections

Citrobacter is a known nosocomial pathogen as well

Klebsiella ozaenae is known to cause secondary atrophic rhinitis

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page 409

choices.text: Recovery of facial nerve is nearly universal
Site of viral activation is geniculate ganglion

questions.text: Which is not true about Ramsay Hunt syndrome
questions.solution:
RAMSAY HUNT SYNDROME-

  • Also known as Herpes zoster oticus.
  • It is due to reactivation of Varicella zoster virus in Geniculate ganglion of facial Nerve

Clinical features

  1. Painful vesicle in external ear.
  2. 7th nerve- Lower motor neuron facial palsy (ipsilateral)
  • Treatment- Acyclovir and steroid therapy.
  • Recovery is seen in 50% patients only.


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P L Dhingra, 8th Edition, Chapter name: Facial Nerve and its Disorders, Page number: 114

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman was brought in by her daughter for a complete physical examination. Her complaints include a poor appetite, weight loss, cramps and weakness. She was diagnosed with Crohn's disease 10 years ago but is not taking any medications. Routine evaluation showed a serum calcium of 7 mg/dl with normal phosphate. She has a creatinine of 0.8 mg/dl, albumin is 3.5 g/dl (normal range, 3.7-4.9 g/dl) and alkaline phosphatase is 350 U/l (normal range, 50-200 U/l). Which of the following diagnoses is most compatible with these lab data?
questions.solution:
• This patient is suffering from Crohn's disease which most commonly affects the terminal ileum; This interferes with the reabsorption of bile acids leading to steatorrhea, inadequate absorption of fat soluble vitamins and weight loss
  • In vitamin D deficiency, decreased intestinal absorption of calcium leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which increases renal tubular loss of phosphate.
  • Vitamin D deficiency can result from inadequate dietary intake, lack of sun exposure and malabsorption in this case due to the long-standing Crohn's disease.
  • Renal failure impairs 1α hydroxylation of 25-hydroxyvitamin D, which results in the malabsorption of calcium. The body compensates by increased secretion of PTH, leading to increased mobilization of calcium from bone.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 3188

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman in Finland suffers from macrocytic anemia. Her history is significant for frequent consumption of pickled fish. A stool sample reveals parasitic ova like the one shown in the figure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Patient Presentation:

  • A 62-year-old woman in Finland.
  • Suffers from macrocytic anemia.

Relevant History:

  • History of frequent consumption of pickled fish.

Stool Sample Findings:

  • Stool sample reveals parasitic ova.

Likely Diagnosis:

  • C) Diphyllobothrium latum is the likely diagnosis.

Rationale for the Diagnosis:

  • Diphyllobothrium latum is a fish tapeworm known to cause diphyllobothriasis.
  • Diphyllobothriasis can lead to macrocytic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • The patient's history of consuming raw or undercooked fish, especially pickled fish, is significant, as this is a common route of infection for Diphyllobothrium latum.
  • Diphyllobothrium latum is prevalent in regions like Finland, where the practice of eating raw pickled fish is prevalent.

In summary, the likely diagnosis for this patient's condition is Diphyllobothrium latum (Choice C). The patient's history and stool sample findings are consistent with this diagnosis.

Reference: Paniker's textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. 120

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents with palpitations and heat intolerance. On examination her pulse is 90/min and a small, diffuse goitre is noted which is tender to touch. Thyroid function tests show the following:
Free T4 24 pmol/l(8-20)
TSH < 0.05 mu/l(0.5-4.5)
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Thyrotoxicosis with tender goitre = subacute (De Quervain's) thyroiditis
  • Whilst Grave's disease is the most common cause of thyrotoxicosis it would not cause a tender goitre.
  • In the context of thyrotoxicosis this finding is specific for De Quervain's thyroiditis.
  • Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder of the thyroid gland. It is typically associated with hypothyroidism although there may be a transient thyrotoxicosis in the acute phase(Hashitoxicosis). The goitre is non-tender in Hashimoto's.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition page 2943

questions.text: Which of the following is best described by the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts smothering. Smothering is a form of asphyxia, caused by mechanical occlusion of external air passages, i.e., nose and mouth by hand/s, cloth, pillow, plastic bag or any other material.

Bruises or abrasions on the cheeks, around the mouth, lips or lesions within the lips or mouth are the features of smothering.

Mechanical asphyxia can be classified depending on the respiratory block:

  1. Compression / constriction of the neck- Hanging, strangulation, throttling
  2. Blocking external orifices of respiration, i.e., mouth and/or nostrils - Smothering, overlying, suffocation, gagging
  3. Impaction of foreign bodies in respiratory tract - Choking
  4. Compression and mechanical fixation of the chest and abdomen preventing the respiratory movements - Traumatic asphyxia / crush asphyxia
  5. Inhalation of fluid into the respiratory tract - Drowning

Burking: It is a form of asphyxia, caused by the combination of Smothering and Traumatic asphyxia

Throttling or Manual strangulation: It is a form of strangulation in which neck is constricted by using hand/hands

Choking: It is a form of asphyxia, caused by occlusion of internal air passage, usually by a solid object, but may be by blood

References: Essentials of Autopsy Practice: Advances, Updates and Emerging Technologies, Page No. 23; The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 280

questions.text: The risk of which of the following is increased by Empagliflozin?
questions.solution:
• Empagliflozin belongs the class of SGLT2 inhibitors
  • SGLT2 transporter is concerned with reabsorption of glucose from proximal tubules of kidneys
  • Inhibition of SGLT2 results in glucosuria and decrease in renal threshold for glucose excretion
  • An important side effect of these class of drugs is increased risk of Diabetic ketoacidosis which may occur at normal or slightly elevated blood glucose (Euglycemic DKA)
  • Recurrent genitourinary infections is also a feature
  • Other specific warnings issued by FDA regarding the use of individual drugs are:
    • Canagliflozin - lower limb amputation, upper extremity fractures, hyperkalemia
    • Dapagliflozin - Bladder cancer

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition page 3110-3111

questions.text: A superior police officer induces his female subordinate to have consensual sexual intercourse by offering promotion in her job. After getting the promotion, the subordinate lodges a complaint. The superior police officer is liable under:
questions.solution:
A person in authority (superior police officer), who induces or seduces any female (subordinate) to have sexual intercourse with him is explained under Section 68 BNS. Such sexual intercourse does not amount to the offense of rape.

Section 68 BNS: - Sexual intercourse by a person in authority

Whoever, being-

  1. in a position of authority or in a fiduciary relationship; or
  2. a public servant; or
  3. superintendent or manager of a jail, remand home or other place of custody established by or under any law for the time being in force, or a women's or children's institution; or
  4. on the management of a hospital or being on the staff of a hospital, abuses such position or fiduciary relationship to induce or seduce any woman either in his custody or under his charge or present in the premises to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offence of rape, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than 5 years, but which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

References: The Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhitha, 2023, The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page No. 321

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a history of dyspnoea and palpitations. On examination he has a jerky carotid pulse, an ejection systolic murmur is audible at the base of the heart which enhances on standing and Valsalva and a pan systolic murmur at the apex. Echocardiography shows asymmetric left ventricular hypertrophy and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve. The patient's symptoms may be treated with:
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HCM) as suggested by the signs of jerky pulse, ejection systolic murmur which intensifies on standing and on performing Valsalva maneuver and echocardiographic findings. Other notable findings which may be seen on clinical examination include pulsus bisferiens and double apex beat.

HCM should be suspected in a young previously well individual presenting with sudden onset arrhythmia especially VT or VF.

Medical therapy of choice in such patients are β-blockers and verapamil (non-dihydropyridine CCB) either alone or in combination. Disopyramide is also used as second line treatment with persistent symptoms

Drugs to be avoided in management include ACE inhibitors / ARBs, nitrates, dihydropyridine CCBs, digoxin, diuretics etc.

Patients at high risk of sudden cardiac death like those with sustained ventricular tachycardia, syncope, LV septal thickness more than 3 cm, family history of sudden cardiac death etc should be treated with Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (ICD) implantation.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1970

questions.text: Which of the following is most resistant to antiseptics?
questions.solution:
Reference: CDC Guideline for Disinfection and Sterilization in Healthcare Facilities (2008)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Chapter 3, Pg 28-29

questions.text: A 66-year-old lady, post-myocardial infarction, is suspected to have a left ventricular apical thrombus. What is the most suitable imaging technique for confirming this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most suitable imaging technique for confirming the presence of a left ventricular apical thrombus is Transthoracic Echocardiography (Option D).

  • Transthoracic Echocardiography (TTE) is the initial imaging modality of choice in evaluating cardiac structure and function. It is non-invasive and can provide real-time images of the heart. In the case of a suspected left ventricular apical thrombus, TTE can visualize the thrombus directly, allowing for a reliable diagnosis.
  • Cardiac MR (Option A): Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging is a powerful tool for assessing cardiac structure and function. While it can detect thrombi, it is typically used for more detailed evaluation after an initial diagnosis has been made, often with TTE.
  • Left Ventricular Angiography (Option B): This involves injecting contrast dye into the coronary arteries to visualize the heart's chambers. While it can detect thrombi, it's an invasive procedure and this technique carries a risk of dislodging and embolisation of the intraventricular thrombus, So it's generally reserved for cases where other imaging methods like TTE have provided inconclusive results or when planning interventions.
  • Multiple Uptake Gated Acquisition Scanning (Option C): This is not a standard imaging technique for evaluating cardiac thrombi. It's more commonly used in nuclear medicine for assessing myocardial perfusion and function.

In summary, while multiple imaging modalities can contribute to the evaluation of cardiac thrombi, Transthoracic Echocardiography (TTE) is typically the initial and most suitable choice due to its non-invasive nature and direct visualization capabilities.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page no: 2065

questions.text: Naegleria fowleri infection is usually transmitted by:
questions.solution:
Option B - Naegleria fowleri is a free-living amoeba which thrives in warm water at low oxygen tension and is commonly found in warm fresh water of lakes, rivers and springs. Infection is acquired by swimming or diving in water containing this amoeba.

Option A - Acanthamoeba (another free-living amoeba) infection can be acquired by ingestion of cyst.

Option C - Though this amoeba is present in soil like acanthamoeba, it usually does not enter through skin penetration. As only trophozoite forms are infective forms and not cysts, and trophozoites do not survive long in soil. Larva of hookworm and S.stercoralis can survive for long in soil and can enter the body through skin penetration.

Option D - Toxoplasma, trypanosomes, Plasmodium and leishmania infection can be acquired through laboratory accidents.

Reference: Paniker’s textbook of Parasitology - 8th Edition, Pg. No. 27

questions.text:
A 58-year-old female presented to her family doctor with pain in the left side of her neck radiating down the lateral aspect of her arm and forearm. She had also noticed some weakness of her left shoulder and struggled to elevate her arm. She had a longstanding history of rheumatoid arthritis, treated with steroids and penicillamine. She was a non-smoker and did not drink any alcohol. On examination there was some wasting over the left deltoid and evidence of fasciculations. Neck movements appeared full except that lateral movement exacerbated the left arm pain. On examination of the upper limb, tone appeared reduced at the elbow and wrist and the biceps jerk was only present on re-enforcement. The left supinator jerk was inverted and the triceps jerk appeared brisk. There was some weakness of left shoulder abduction, elbow flexion and supination, but finger movements and elbow extension were intact. There was a sensory deficit over the lateral aspect of the left upper arm and forearm. The right arm appeared normal. On examination of her lower limb, tone was increased, but power appeared normal. All reflexes were brisk and both plantar responses were extensor.
Investigations showed:
Haemoglobin 11.4 g/dl(13.0 18.0 g/dL)
White cell count 3.4 x 10^9/L (4 11 x 10^9/L)
Platelets 245 x 10^9/L (150 400 x 10^9/L)
ESR (Westergren) 45 mm/1st hour (0-15 mm/1st hour)
Serum Sodium 145 mmol/L(137-144 mmol/L)
Serum Potassium 3.2 mmol/L (3.5-4.9)
Serum urea 66 mg/dl (high)
Serum Creatinine 1.6 g/dl (high)
Serum creatine kinase 178 U/L (2D-170 U/L)
Fasting blood glucose 136 (high)
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This patient has a cervical myelopathy, most likely as a result of her rheumatoid arthritis.
  • The likely level is C5/C6 given that there is weakness of the deltoid, biceps and supinator and the supinator jerk is inverted. She also has long tract signs in her legs with hypertonia and hyperreflexia.
  • A circumflex neuropathy would account for the weakness and fasciculations of the deltoid, but would not explain the upper motor neuron signs in the legs, or weakness of the biceps and supinator.
  • Inclusion body myositis, an inflammatory myopathy, would present with bilateral often asymmetrical weakness, which has a tendency to affect distal musculature. The tendon reflexes would be normal and the creatine kinase would be normal or mildly elevated.
  • Motor neuron disease presents with upper and lower motor signs in absence of sensory disturbance .
  • A steroid induced myopathy would cause proximal weakness and wasting with normal reflexes and sensation.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Ed, Ch: 442, Pg: 3452

questions.text: A 50-year-old politician presented with a strange fluttering sensation in his chest, but no chest pain. The symptoms lasted 24 hours. An ECG revealed atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 130 beats per minute. His blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Which one of the following drugs is most likely to restore sinus rhythm?
questions.solution:
• A patient with atrial fibrillation and hemodynamic instability (hypotension/shock/impaired consciousness/heart failure/angina) is treated with DC cardioversion.
  • In a patient with AF without hemodynamic instability, the two approaches to management include controlling the heart rate or restoring sinus rhythm.
  • Flecainide is the drug most likely to restore sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation. Other drugs include Amiodarone, sotalol, dronedarone, propafenone etc.
  • Adenosine is used in patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).
  • Digoxin and Bisoprolol are indicated for rate control and are not normally associated with the restoration of sinus rhythm.
  • Verapamil can be used for rate control in atrial fibrillation, and may be used in the treatment of SVT.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1907

questions.text: Cadmium causes:
questions.solution:
Cadmium causes proximal tubular necrosis.

Postmortem findings in cadmium poisoning:

  1. GIT: Mucous membranes of the oesophagus, stomach and intestines are congested and inflamed.
  2. Lungs: Pulmonary edema and emphysema. There may be degeneration and/or loss of bronchial and bronchiolar epithelial cells.
  3. Heart and liver: Fatty degeneration.
  4. Kidneys: Proximal tubular necrosis (interstitial nephritis in chronic cases).
  5. Brain: Congested.

Reference: Review of Forensic medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 5th edition, Page No. 560

questions.text: A 77-year-old lady has four months of memory loss, urinary incontinence and falls. On examination she has mild memory loss and a broad-based, slow gait. Muscle tone is normal and both plantar reflexes are down going. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is characterised by abnormal gait, urinary incontinence, and dementia.

It is an important clinical diagnosis, because it is a potentially reversible cause of dementia.

Frontal lobe dementia is characterised by loss of 'executive' functions and multi-infarct state usually has a step-wise history.

TO SUMMARIZE, THE VARIOUS DEMENTIAS

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 431, Pg: 3375

choices.text: Cluster headache is more common in males than in females

questions.text: A 40 year old male presents with history of recurrent episodes of left retroorbital pain. It occurs one or two times in a day and lasts for around 1 or two hours. During the episodes the patient seems agitated and is associated with lacrimation. He gets such attacks for around 1 or two months after which he remains asymptomatic, just to get recurrence of such attacks in the future. Which of the following statements is false
questions.solution:
This question deals with the clinical features of Cluster head ache. Cluster head ache has a male preponderance among the Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalagias. The other TACs are Paroxysmal Hemicrania and SUNCT/SUNA occur in equal frequency in males and females.

Cluster head ache has a definite association with alcohol intake, whereas, the other two does not have any association.

Among the TACs Paroxysmal Hemicrania is the only headache having a responsiveness to Indomethacin.

Treatment of Cluster Head ache:

  • Acute attack:
    • Respond well to oxygen inhalation as 100% oxygen at 10-15 L/min for 15-20 minutes.
    • Sumatriptan 6 mg SC is rapid in onset and will usually shorten an attack to 10-15 min.
    • Sumatriptan (20 mg) and zolmitriptan (5 mg) nasal sprays are both effective in acute cluster headache, offering a useful option for patients who may not wish to self-inject daily.
    • Oral sumatriptan is not effective for prevention or for acute treatment of cluster headache.
  • Neurostimulation therapy:
    • When medical therapies fail in chronic cluster headache, neurostimulation strategies can be employed.
    • Deep-brain stimulation of the region of the posterior hypothalamic gray matter has proven successful in a substantial proportion of patients.
    • Non-invasive vagal nerve stimulation is FDA approved using three 2-min stimulation cycles applied consecutively at the onset of headache on the side of pain. This may be repeated after 9 minutes

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed, Ch: 430, Pg: 3366-3367

questions.text: All of the following strategies done for Damage control resuscitation except:
questions.solution:
The four central strategies of DCR are:

  1. Anticipate and treat acute traumatic coagulopathy.
  2. Permissive hypotension until hemorrhage control.
  3. Limit crystalloid and colloid infusion to avoid dilutional coagulopathy.
  4. Damage control surgery to control hemorrhage and preserve physiology.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 2, Edition: 28th, Pg: 16-17

questions.text: Which of the vitamin deficiency occurs in maize eating population
questions.solution:
1. Beri-Beri: Beriberi is a condition caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is commonly associated with a diet that lacks adequate sources of thiamine, such as polished rice. While maize consumption alone does not directly cause beriberi, diets predominantly consisting of polished grains like rice can lead to thiamine deficiency.
  2. Megaloblastic anaemia: Megaloblastic anaemia is primarily caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. It is not directly associated with maize consumption. However, if a diet high in maize lacks sources of vitamin B12 and folate, it could contribute to the development of megaloblastic anaemia.
  3. Pellagra: Pellagra is caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Maize is a staple food in many regions, particularly where it is consumed as a major dietary component. Unfortunately, maize lacks sufficient amounts of niacin, and it also contains compounds like niacinamide that interfere with niacin absorption. Therefore, populations relying heavily on maize as a dietary staple are at risk of developing pellagra due to insufficient niacin intake.
  4. Night blindness: Night blindness is primarily associated with vitamin A deficiency. While maize consumption alone does not directly cause night blindness, diets deficient in vitamin A can lead to this condition. Maize itself is not a significant source of vitamin A, so populations relying heavily on maize may be at risk of vitamin A deficiency if their diet lacks other sources of this essential nutrient.

In summary, pellagra (option c) is the correct answer because it directly relates to niacin deficiency, which can occur in populations with a heavy reliance on maize as a staple food due to its inadequate niacin content and bioavailability.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 734

choices.text: Give a dose of TT & explain to her that it will not protect the newborn & she should take the second dose after 4 weeks even if she if delivers in the meantime
Do not waste the TT vaccine as it would anyhow be of no use in this pregnancy
Given one dose of TT, explain it will not be useful for this pregnancy
Give anti-tetanus immunoglobulin along with the TT vaccine

questions.text: 37 weeks pregnant woman attends an antenatal clinic at a PHC. She has not had any antenatal care till now. The best approach here regarding TT immunisation would be
questions.solution:
The best approach regarding TT immunization for a 37-week pregnant woman attending an antenatal clinic at a Primary Health Centre (PHC) who has not had any antenatal care till now would be option A: Give a dose of TT & explain to her that it will not protect the newborn & she should take the second dose after 4 weeks even if she delivers in the meantime.

  • This option is the best approach because administering Tetanus Toxoid (TT) vaccine at this stage of pregnancy can provide some level of protection against tetanus for the mother during delivery and for the newborn.
  • Even though the full course of TT vaccination requires multiple doses for optimal protection, giving at least one dose of TT at this late stage of pregnancy can still offer some benefit.
  • By explaining to the woman that this dose will not fully protect the newborn and advising her to take the second dose after 4 weeks regardless of whether she delivers in the meantime, healthcare providers can ensure that she receives appropriate follow-up care for tetanus prevention.

Why the other options are not correct:

Option B: Do not waste the TT vaccine as it would anyhow be of no use in this pregnancy:

  • This option is not recommended because administering TT vaccine, even at this late stage, can still provide some level of protection against tetanus for the mother during delivery.
  • While one dose may not fully protect the newborn, it can still offer some benefit to the mother, and it sets the stage for follow-up vaccination after delivery.

Option C: Given one dose of TT, explain it will not be useful for this pregnancy:

  • Simply giving the TT vaccine without providing proper information about its limitations and follow-up care may lead to confusion or misunderstanding on the part of the pregnant woman.
  • It's essential to educate the woman about the purpose and timing of TT vaccination to ensure that she understands the importance of follow-up care.

Option D: Give anti-tetanus immunoglobulin along with the TT vaccine:

  • Administering anti-tetanus immunoglobulin is not typically indicated for routine antenatal care unless there is a specific indication, such as a tetanus-prone wound or a history of incomplete or inadequate TT vaccination.
  • Using immunoglobulin alongside TT vaccine in this scenario would not be appropriate without a specific indication for its use.

In summary, option A is the best approach because it provides some level of protection against tetanus for the mother and sets the stage for follow-up vaccination after delivery, while also ensuring that the woman receives proper information about the limitations of the vaccine and the need for additional doses.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 604

questions.text: You perform streak retinoscopy on a cycloplegic infant. With the streak oriented vertically at 90°, you neutralize the reflex with a -2.00 D lens (after subtracting the working distance), and with the horizontal streak, +3.00 D lens. What is the cycloplegic refraction?
questions.solution:
• With the streak oriented vertically and by moving it left and right, the power in the 180° meridian (and the power in the 90° axis) is actually being evaluated–likewise, when the beam is rotated 90°.
  • This evaluation can be represented on the power cross in Figure 3-27.
  • The astigmatism is the difference between the two lenses, or +5.00 D. The final prescription is −2.00 + 5.00 × 180°.

Reference: Khurana Optics 2/e, P. 35

questions.text: All of the following are transmission cycles of Japanese Encephalitis except:
questions.solution:
• Man is a dead end host for Japanese Encephalitis. So no such transmission cycles exist.
  • Japanese encephalitis virus is the leading cause of vaccine preventable viral encephalitis in Asia, including India. It belongs to the family Flaviviridae. It is an enveloped virus, containing ssRNA.
  • Transmission cycle: JE virus infects several non-human hosts, e.g. animals and birds. Two transmission cycles are predominant
  • Pigs → Culex → Pigs Ardeid birds → Culex → Ardeid birds.

Animal hosts: JE virus has several animal hosts.

  • Pigs have been incriminated as the major vertebrate host for JE. JE virus multiplies exponentially in pigs without causing any manifestation. Pigs are considered as the amplifier host for JE.
  • Cattle and buffaloes may also be infected with JE virus; although they are not the natural host. They may act as mosquito attractants.
  • Horses are probably the only animals to be symptomatic and develop encephalitis following JE virus infection.
  • Humans are considered as dead ends; there is no man → mosquito → man cycle (unlike in dengue).
  • Bird hosts: Ardeid (wading) birds such as herons, cattle egrets, and ducks can also be involved in the natural cycle of JE virus.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 717

questions.text: 'A' kills 'B' with a knife. Another person 'Z' saw 'A' with knife in the park few minutes before murder. 'Z' gives this statement in court of law. What kind of evidence is it?
questions.solution:
ORAL EVIDENCE

  1. Direct: Evidence of a fact which is actually in issue, e.g., an electric blanket that has caused injury, prescription, or a consent form.
  2. Indirect or Circumstantial: It is not the direct testimony of an eye witness, but has a bearing upon the fact of the other and subsidiary facts which are relied upon as consistent, e.g., in case of alleged murder of A by B at certain place on a particular day and time, the circumstantial evidence would be that C saw B with a knife on that day at that place, a few minutes before the murder. Circumstantial evidence requires the Court to draw logical or reasonable inferences from the information presented.
  3. Hearsay: It is any statement made by any person about what he did not personally witness, or evidence he obtained from a third party, which is presented in the Court in order to assert that the facts contained in the statement are true, e.g., A gives evidence in the witness box stating that B had informed him that he had seen C committing a crime. In such case direct evidence can be given only by B that he had seen C committing a crime.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, K S Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 9

questions.text: A 52 year old female patient suffering from thyroid carcinoma underwent total thyroidectomy. During surgery, both side recurrent laryngeal nerves got damaged. Which of the following will be the procedure needed in this case in future?

This is a case of bilateral abductor palsy. The immediate treatment will be emergency tracheostomy. Then we wait for 6 months, if patient shows no recovery, then the treatment of choice is vocal cord lateralization (type 2 thyroplasty). It is also called suture cordopexy of the vocal cord.

Kashima operation is also useful. In this surgery, CO2 laser is used to separate the membranous and cartilaginous part of the vocal cords so that there is some space created for the airway.

Woodman's operation is arytenoidectomy by open approach. This can also be done

questions.text: All of the following bacteria test 'Urease positive' EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Proteus, Klebsiella and Staphylococcus aureus are Urease positive.
  • E coli are urease negative.
  • Urea Agar was developed by Christensen in 1946 for the differentiation of enteric bacilli. The urease test is used to determine the ability of an organism to split urea, through the production of the enzyme urease.
  • Principle of Urease Test : Urea is the product of decarboxylation of amino acids. Hydrolysis of urea produces ammonia and CO2. The formation of ammonia alkalinizes the medium, and the pH shift is detected by the color change of phenol red from light orange at pH 6.8 to magenta (pink) at pH 8.1. Rapid urease-positive organisms turn the entire medium pink within 24 hours. Weakly positive organisms may take several days, and negative organisms produce no color change or yellow as a result of acid production.

  • Positive Reaction: Development of an intense magenta to bright pink color in 15 min to 24h.
    • Examples: Proteus spp, Cryptococcus spp, Corynebacterium spp, Helicobacter pylori, Yersinia spp, Brucella spp, etc.
  • Negative Reaction: No color change.
    • Examples: Escherichia, Shigella, Salmonella, etc.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition pg 33

questions.text: Identify the fingerprint pattern shown in the image:
questions.solution:
• An arch fingerprint pattern is the simplest and least common type.
  • It appears as a continuous wave-like pattern without any deltas or cores. In an arch pattern, the ridges enter from one side of the fingerprint and exit from the opposite side, forming a slight upward or downward curve.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A: Whorl: A whorl fingerprint pattern consists of two deltas and a circular core, which is not seen in the given image.
  • Option B: Composite: Composite patterns are combinations of different types of fingerprints and are more complex, which is not applicable here.
  • Option C: Loop: Loop patterns have one delta and a core, with ridges looping around, which is also not seen in the given image.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Arch appears as a continuous wave-like pattern without any deltas or cores. In an arch pattern, the ridges enter from one side of the fingerprint and exit from the opposite side, forming a slight upward or downward curve.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd editio, Page no: 85.

questions.text: A 35 year old man has significant wheezing and breathlessness. Recordings of peak flows show diurnal variation. He was prescribed salbutamol but continues to have frequent wheezy episodes. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
• Diurnal PEFR variation points towards a diagnosis of asthma. GINA does not recommend SABA only treatment for asthma in adults and adolescents and does not recommend the scheduled day use of SABAs.
  • Although SABA is effective as a quick relief medication, patients who are treated with SABA are at increased risk for asthma-related death even if their symptoms are controlled. Increased use (more than one canister a month) indicates diminished asthma control and the need for adding long term therapy.

  • Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than inhaled corticosteroids for exacerbation reduction but may be considered as alternatives in patients with asthma who are unable to take inhaled corticosteroids or who experience undesirable steroid side effects.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Ed, Ch: 287, Pg: 2158

questions.text: Runt disease is:
questions.solution:
Graft versus host reaction (GVHR) - called Runt disease in animals.

  • Graft versus host - graft mounts an immune response against antigens of the host.
  • GVH occurs when the following conditions are present:
    • Graft contains immunocompetent cells.
    • Recipients possess transplantation antigens that are absent in the graft.
    • Recipients must not reject the graft.
  • Situations leading to GVH-
    • Allograft in recipient in whom specific immunological tolerance has been induced.
    • Adult lymphocytes injected into an immunologically deficient recipient.
    • F1 hybrid receiving a transplant from any one parental strain.
  • Clinical features of GVHR-
    • Retardation of growth, emaciation
    • Diarrhea, hepatosplenomegaly
    • Lymphoid atrophy, anaemia
    • Terminating fatally

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 12th edition Chapter 18, Pg 266

questions.text:
A 5-day old neonate had respiratory distress which progressed to meningitis in the next 2 days. You were sent to microbiology laboratory with a sample swab to perform the following culture method shown in the image:

Label A in the image denotes the presence of which bacteria in the specimen?
questions.solution:
Group B Streptococci (S. agalactiae) Approximately 30% of women are vaginal or rectal carriers of group B Streptococci (CBS). Hence, the CBS infection is common in neonates and in pregnancy.

  • Group B Streptococci has been recognized as a major cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

Neonatal sepsis can be of two types-early onset and late onset type.

  • Infections in pregnancy can lead to peripartum fever in women.
  • Infections in adults generally involve elderly or people with underlying chronic illness, such as diabetes mellitus or malignancy.

It is catalase negative like all Streptococci.

To differentiate following tests are done:

CAMP positive: CAMP factor (named after the discoverers: Chrislie, Atkins-Munch-Petersen) is a phospholipase produced by GBS that causes synergistic hemolysis with beta hemolysin produced by S. aureus. When GBS is streaked on blood agar plate perpendicular to S. aureus, an enhanced arrow head shaped hemolysis is produced at their junction, pointing towards the GBS streak line.

  • Hippurate hydrolysis test positive
  • Bacitracin resistant
  • PYR is negative
  • Beta hemolytic colonies are mucoid and slightly larger

Streptococcus dysgalactiae is a Group C Streptococci.

Clostridium perfringens shows Reverse CAMP test.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Microbiology, by Apurba Sastry and Sandhya Bhat, 3rd edition, page no: 525

  • Berylliosis

questions.text: As compared to Cow's milk, human milk has
questions.solution:
Option C: More Iron:

  • Human milk contains more iron compared to cow's milk.
  • Iron content in human milk is adapted to meet the iron needs of human infants during the first six months of life, as they are born with iron stores that gradually deplete over time.
  • While cow's milk naturally contains very little iron, human milk provides a readily absorbable form of iron that supports the infant's growth and development.

Why the other options are not correct:

Option A: More proteins:

  • Human milk typically contains less protein compared to cow's milk.
  • While both human and cow's milk contain protein, human milk is specifically designed to meet the needs of human infants, and its protein content is tailored to their requirements.
  • Cow's milk has a higher protein content, which is suitable for the rapid growth of calves but may be excessive for human infants and potentially strain their immature kidneys.

Option B: Less carbohydrate:

  • Human milk contains more carbohydrates compared to cow's milk.
  • Carbohydrates in human milk primarily come from lactose, a type of sugar that provides essential energy for the growing infant.
  • Cow's milk contains less lactose and more non-lactose carbohydrates, such as oligosaccharides and complex sugars, which are less easily digestible for human infants.

Option D: Less Vitamin C, D:

  • Human milk typically contains less Vitamin D compared to cow's milk.
  • Vitamin D content in breast milk is relatively low, and breastfed infants may require supplementation or exposure to sunlight to meet their Vitamin D needs.
  • Vitamin C content may vary, but it is typically similar in both human and cow's milk and is not significantly lower in human milk.

In summary, while human milk and cow's milk differ in various nutritional components, human milk typically contains more iron compared to cow's milk. This is essential for meeting the iron needs of human infants during the critical early months of life.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 744, 616

questions.text: In hysterosalpingography, fallopian tubes are seen beaded in appearance with clubbing of the fimbrial end and ampulla. What is likely cause:
questions.solution:
HSG showing 'Bead-like fallopian tube and clubbing of ampulla are suggestive of genital tuberculosis'

HSG findings in case of tuberculosis:

Rigid non-peristaltic pipe like tube called as lead pipe appearance.

  • Beading of tube and variation in filling density.
  • Elongated and distended tube with everted fimbriae and patent abdominal ostium called 'tobacco pouch' appearance.
  • Calcification of tube, Bilateral cornual block.
  • Vascular or lymphatic intravasation of dye.
  • Tubal diverticula
  • Uterine cavity - irregular outline, honeycomb appearance or presence of uterine synechiae (Asherman's syndrome).

In a proven case of genital tuberculosis, HSG is contraindicated as it may spread the infection. So, HSG should not be performed until pelvic tuberculosis is excluded by endometrial study.

Reference: Dutta Gynae 5th/ed p 137-38

choices.text: DR begins to decline, while the BR remains unchanged
DR declines still further and BR tends to fall

questions.text: True about late expanding stage of demographic cycle
questions.solution:
The late expanding stage of the demographic cycle is characterized by specific demographic trends as a country progresses through economic and social development.

c. DR declines still further and BR tends to fall:

This statement accurately describes the trends seen in the late expanding stage. As countries progress through this stage, both birth rates and death rates continue to decline, albeit at different rates. Improved healthcare, education, and access to family planning services often lead to a decline in both birth and death rates during this stage, with birth rates eventually tending to fall more rapidly than death rates.

Why the other options are not correct:

a. BR is lower than DR:

This statement is not true for the late expanding stage. In this stage, birth rates (BR) typically remain relatively high, often higher than death rates (DR), contributing to population growth. So, BR being lower than DR would not be characteristic of this stage.

b. DR begins to decline, while the BR remains unchanged:

While it is true that death rates (DR) may begin to decline during the late expanding stage due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and living standards, birth rates (BR) also tend to decline, although not necessarily simultaneously. The statement implies that BR remains unchanged, which is not typical for this stage. Birth rates usually start to fall, although they may still be higher than death rates.

d. High BR and high DR:

This statement might describe an earlier stage of demographic transition, such as the early expanding stage or even the pre-transitional stage. However, in the late expanding stage, while birth rates may still be relatively high compared to developed countries, death rates begin to decline, resulting in a lower overall mortality rate compared to earlier stages. So, high death rates are not characteristic of the late expanding stage.

In summary, option "c" is true for the late expanding stage because it accurately reflects the ongoing decline in death rates and the tendency for birth rates to fall as a country progresses through this stage of demographic transition.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION, Pg no: 554

questions.text: XDR TB means resistance to
questions.solution:
(d) INH, Rifampicin, Amikacin & Levofloxacin: This combination includes resistance to INH, Rifampicin, a second-line injectable drug (Amikacin), and a fluoroquinolone (Levofloxacin). XDR TB is defined as resistance to at least these four categories of drugs, making this option the correct choice.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

(a) INH & Rifampicin: INH (Isoniazid) and Rifampicin are the two most important first-line drugs used in the treatment of tuberculosis (TB). XDR TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) is defined as resistance to at least INH, Rifampicin, a fluoroquinolone (such as Levofloxacin), and at least one of the injectable second-line drugs (such as Amikacin).

(b) INH, Rifampicin, Kanamycin & Amikacin: This combination includes Kanamycin and Amikacin, which are both injectable second-line drugs used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). However, XDR TB requires resistance to a fluoroquinolone (such as Levofloxacin) rather than Kanamycin.

(c) INH, Rifampicin, Ofloxacin & Pyrazinamide: While this combination includes Rifampicin and a fluoroquinolone (Ofloxacin), it lacks resistance to both INH and Pyrazinamide, which are essential components to be considered XDR TB.

In summary, XDR TB refers to tuberculosis that is resistant to at least INH, Rifampicin, a fluoroquinolone, and at least one of the injectable second-line drugs. Therefore, option (d) is the correct choice as it includes resistance to the necessary combination of drugs for XDR TB.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION, Pg 211

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for development of the pathology depicted in the picture below except?
questions.solution:
Subconjunctival hemorrhage, also called subconjunctival ecchymosis, is due to the rupture of small vessels.

  • The condition, though unsightly, is trivial.
  • This can occur spontaneously in elderly people with fragile vessels or those with systolic hypertension or after local ocular trauma or eye surgery.
  • Very minute ecchymoses, or possibly thromboses, are seen in severe conjunctivitis; large extravasations accompany severe straining, especially in old people, such as on lifting heavy weights or vomiting.
  • They are not infrequently seen in children with whooping cough and may occur in scurvy, in blood diseases such as purpura or in malaria. Rickets is caused by Vit D deficiency, not a known risk factor for SCH.
  • It is self-resolving in two to three weeks' time. No treatment is required

Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye-Edition 23-Chap 11-Diseases of the Conjunctiva

questions.text: Which one of the following is not used for testing adequate pasteurization of milk
questions.solution:
d. Methylene blue reduction test: This test is not typically used to assess the adequacy of pasteurization. The methylene blue reduction test is commonly employed to evaluate the quality of raw milk and detect the presence of bacteria that are capable of reducing methylene blue dye. However, it is not specifically designed to assess the effectiveness of pasteurization in killing harmful microorganisms.

Why the other options are not correct:

a. Phosphatase test: Phosphatase is an enzyme naturally present in raw milk. Pasteurization should effectively destroy phosphatase activity, as it is a heat-sensitive enzyme. Therefore, testing for the presence of phosphatase in milk after pasteurization can indicate whether the milk has been adequately pasteurized. If phosphatase is detected, it suggests that the milk may not have been heated sufficiently to kill harmful microorganisms.

b. Coliform count: Coliform bacteria are a group of bacteria commonly used as indicators of sanitation and faecal contamination in food and water. While coliform bacteria are not harmful themselves, their presence in milk can indicate poor sanitation during milk production or processing. Testing for coliform counts after pasteurization helps ensure that the milk has been effectively treated to kill any harmful bacteria present.

c. Standard plate count: The standard plate count measures the total number of viable bacteria present in a sample of milk. This count includes both beneficial and harmful bacteria. After pasteurization, the number of viable bacteria should be significantly reduced, indicating that the milk has been adequately heated to kill harmful pathogens. Therefore, testing the standard plate count can help verify the effectiveness of pasteurization.

In summary, option D (Methylene blue reduction test) is the correct answer because it is not commonly used for testing the adequate pasteurization of milk. Options A, B, and C are all methods used to assess the effectiveness of pasteurization and ensure the safety and quality of milk for consumption.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION, Pg 769

questions.text: 45 year old female presented with symptoms of diminished vision since five years, especially at night. Fundus examination revealed pale waxy optic disc, arteriolar attenuation and bony spicules. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fundus changes in retinitis pigmentosa: BAP pneumonic

  • B - BONY SPICULES: Retinal pigmentary changes-These are typically perivascular (around veins) and jet black spots resembling bone corpuscles in shape. lnitially, these changes are found in the equatorial region only and later spread both anteriorly and posteriorly.
  • A - Attenuated vessels: Retinal arterioles are attenuated (narrowed) and may become thread-like in late stages.
  • P - Pale disc
