questions.text: Per capita allowance of water per day is recommended at
questions.solution:
d. 150-200 L: This range is often recommended as the per capita allowance of water per day in many regions. It provides a sufficient amount of water to meet basic needs such as drinking, cooking, sanitation, and hygiene, while also accounting for variations in water consumption patterns and lifestyle factors. It allows for a comfortable level of water use without excessive waste or inefficiency.

Why the other options are not suitable:

a. 70-80 L:This range of water allowance per capita per day is relatively low and may not be sufficient to meet the basic needs of individuals in many regions. It could lead to water scarcity and inadequate access to clean water for drinking, cooking, sanitation, and hygiene purposes.

b. 80-120 L: While this range provides a slightly higher allowance of water per capita per day compared to option a, it may still be insufficient to meet the needs of individuals, especially in regions with higher water consumption requirements or where water-intensive activities such as agriculture or industry are prevalent.

c. 120-150 L: This range offers a moderate allowance of water per capita per day, which may be suitable for meeting basic needs in some regions. However, it could still be insufficient in areas where water scarcity or inefficient water management practices are prevalent.

In summary, option d (150-200 L) is the correct answer because it represents a recommended per capita allowance of water per day that is sufficient to meet basic needs and account for variations in water consumption patterns. The other options offer lower ranges of water allowance that may not adequately meet the needs of individuals or communities.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION, Pg 833

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common late complication of cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Posterior capsule opacification (PCO) is the most common late complication following cataract surgery.

Complications of cataract surgery:

Early postoperative complications: These occur within the first 4 weeks of surgery. These include:

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Uveitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome
  • Posterior vitreous detachment with retinal tear or vitreous haemorrhage
  • Refractive surprise, i.e. high refractive error due to wrong power intraocular lens

Late postoperative complications: These occur after 1 month to years. These include:

  • Posterior capsule opacification - most common
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Late endophthalmitis
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Malposition of intraocular lens - subluxation or dislocation

Reference: Yanoff and Duker 4th edition 402-403 Parson's disease of the eye 23rd edition, page no: 258

choices.text: No preliminary storage of raw water is required
Can be gravity type or pressure type

questions.text: All are true for rapid sand filters except
questions.solution:
The correct answer is C: Frequent washing is not required.

C. Frequent washing is not required: This statement is false. In rapid sand filtration, frequent washing, also known as backwashing, is indeed required to remove accumulated particles and debris from the filter media. Backwashing helps to maintain the filtration efficiency and prevent clogging of the filter bed. Without regular backwashing, the filter performance can deteriorate, leading to decreased water quality and reduced filter lifespan.

Why the other options are not suitable:

A. No preliminary storage of raw water is required: This statement is true for rapid sand filters. Rapid sand filters can operate without the need for preliminary storage of raw water. Instead, the water is fed directly into the filter system for treatment, making the process more efficient.

B. Operation requires highly skilled persons: This statement is true for rapid sand filters. Operating and maintaining rapid sand filters require highly skilled personnel who are knowledgeable about the filtration process, equipment operation, and troubleshooting. This ensures that the filters operate effectively and efficiently to produce safe and clean drinking water.

D. Can be gravity type or pressure type: This statement is true for rapid sand filters. Rapid sand filters can be designed as either gravity filters or pressure filters, depending on the specific requirements of the water treatment system. Gravity filters rely on the force of gravity to move water through the filter bed, while pressure filters use pumps to pressurize the water and force it through the filter media. Both types of filters are commonly used in water treatment plants to remove suspended solids and impurities from raw water.

In summary, option C is the correct answer because frequent washing, or backwashing, is indeed required for rapid sand filters to maintain their effectiveness, contrary to the other options which are true characteristics of rapid sand filters.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION, Pg 840

questions.text: Which class of glaucoma medications should be avoided in a patient with a sulfa allergy?
questions.solution:
• Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors decrease aqueous humor formation by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the ciliary epithelium.
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are frequently used orally (acetazolamide and methazolamide) and topically (dorzolamide and brinzolamide) in the treatment of glaucoma.
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are chemically derived from sulfa drugs, and they may cross react with sulfa drugs.
  • The other classes of glaucoma medications are not sulfa derivatives, and no cross reactivity with sulfa drugs is expected.

Reference: Parsons 22nd edition, pg 157

questions.text: Most commonly reported disease in the post disaster period is
questions.solution:
During the post-disaster period, particularly in the immediate aftermath of a disaster, gastroenteritis (inflammation of the stomach and intestines) is often the most commonly reported disease. This is due to several factors:

  • Contaminated water sources: Disasters such as floods, hurricanes, earthquakes, and tsunamis can disrupt water and sanitation systems, leading to contamination of drinking water sources with sewage, bacteria, viruses, and other pathogens. As a result, individuals may consume contaminated water, leading to gastrointestinal infections such as gastroenteritis.
  • Poor sanitation: Disasters often result in the displacement of populations, overcrowding in temporary shelters, and inadequate sanitation facilities. These conditions increase the risk of faecal-oral transmission of pathogens, as individuals may not have access to proper toilets or hygiene facilities, leading to the spread of gastroenteritis-causing microorganisms.
  • Food contamination: Disasters can also disrupt food supply chains, leading to food shortages, spoilage of perishable food items, and improper storage of food. Consuming contaminated or spoiled food can result in foodborne illnesses, including gastroenteritis.
  • Poor hygiene practices: In the chaotic aftermath of a disaster, individuals may face challenges in maintaining proper hygiene practices such as handwashing with clean water and soap. Lack of access to hygiene facilities and limited availability of clean water can further exacerbate the risk of gastrointestinal infections.

Explanation for why the other options are not correct:

A. Acute respiratory infections:While respiratory infections can occur in the post-disaster period, they are typically not as prevalent as gastroenteritis, especially in situations where water and sanitation systems are disrupted, leading to an increased risk of waterborne and foodborne diseases.

C. Tetanus: Tetanus is a bacterial infection caused by Clostridium tetani, which enters the body through wounds contaminated with soil, dust, or faeces containing the bacterium. While injuries and wounds may occur during disasters, tetanus is not as commonly reported as gastroenteritis in the immediate post-disaster period.

D. Malaria:Malaria is a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Plasmodium parasites. While malaria may be a concern in disaster-affected regions where stagnant water accumulates and provides breeding grounds for mosquitoes, it is typically not the most commonly reported disease in the immediate post-disaster period, especially in regions where malaria transmission is not endemic. Gastroenteritis, on the other hand, is more directly linked to disruptions in water and sanitation systems following disasters.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION, Pg 924

questions.text: Urine bags and catheters disposal in India is by
questions.solution:
B. Red bags: Red bags, also known as biohazard bags, are specifically designated for the disposal of medical waste that is potentially infectious or biohazardous. Urine bags and catheters may come into contact with bodily fluids and are therefore considered biohazardous waste. Disposing of them in red bags helps ensure proper containment and handling to minimize the risk of exposure to pathogens. Therefore, red bags are the appropriate choice for the disposal of urine bags and catheters in India and other medical settings.

Explanation for why the other options is not correct:

A. Yellow bags: Yellow bags are typically used for the disposal of infectious or potentially infectious clinical waste, such as materials contaminated with blood, body fluids, or other potentially infectious substances. While urine bags and catheters may sometimes contain bodily fluids, they are not typically considered infectious waste unless specifically contaminated with blood or pathogens. Therefore, yellow bags are not the appropriate choice for their disposal.

C. White containers: White containers are not typically designated for the disposal of medical waste. In medical settings, white containers may be used for general waste or non-hazardous materials. However, urine bags and catheters are considered medical waste due to their potential contamination with bodily fluids and pathogens, so they require specialized disposal methods.

D. Blue bags: Blue bags are often used for the disposal of recyclable materials or non-infectious waste that does not pose a risk to human health or the environment. While urine bags and catheters are indeed non-infectious in most cases, they are still considered medical waste and should be disposed of accordingly. Blue bags are not specifically intended for medical waste disposal, so they are not the appropriate choice for disposing of urine bags and catheters.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION, Pg 919

choices.text: Stimulation of continuation of reduction division of oocytes

questions.text: True regarding ovulatory phase?
questions.solution:
• Option a: Stimulation of continuation of reduction division of oocytes - correct During oogenesis the primary oocyte is arrested in prophase of meiosis 1. Just before ovulation, the LH surge initiates the continuation of meiosis, forming a secondary oocyte and 1st polar body.
  • The LH surge initiates the resumption of meiosis in the oocyte (meiosis is not completed until after the sperm has entered and the second polar body is released.
  • Option b: Inhibin A is increased in ovulatory phase - incorrect Levels of inhibin A are increased and reach peak in mid luteal phase, not in ovulatory phase.
  • Option c: FSH increases steroid synthesis in granulosa cells- FSH acts on the granulosa cells to produce estrogen mainly in the follicular phase and not in ovulatory phase.
  • Option d: Activin causes FSH to act on the granulosa cells- As discussed, activin does augment the action of FSH on granulosa cells but during early follicular phase and not during ovulatory phase.
  • In the granulosa of the early follicular phase, activin augments FSH activities: FSH receptor expression, aromatization, inhibin/ activin production, and LH receptor expression.
  • In the theca, activin suppresses androgen production, allowing the emergence of an estrogen microenvironment.

questions.text: A 65 year old man has worsening breathlessness. He has a past medical history of arthritis and palpitations. On admission his oxygen saturations were 90% on air. questions.text: A 24-year-old woman came to opd with a complaint of deep pelvic pain and infertility. Best investigation to establish the diagnosis of endometriosis is:
questions.solution:
Diagnostic laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis.

Typical lesion: Powder burn/Gunshot lesions (black, dark brown, or bluish cysts with old hemorrhage surrounded by variable degree of fibrosis)

Other non-typical findings could be:

  • Red implants
  • Serous or clear vesicles
  • White plaques/scarring
  • Yellowish brown discoloration of peritoneum
  • Sub ovarian adhesions
  • Presence of defects in the peritoneum (usually scarring overlying implants) is called Allen masters syndrome.
  • Histological confirmation of laparoscopic impression is essential for diagnosis of endometriosis.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the Figure:

• The clamp is used in myomectomy operation.
  • It curtails the blood supply to the uterus temporarily, thereby minimizing the blood loss during operation.

questions.text: A 9 kg baby with diarrhoea is feeding well and is thirsty. Skin pinch when done returns in 4 seconds. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
This is the correct answer. According to World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines for the management of acute diarrhoea with dehydration in children, ORS should be administered to replace fluid losses and correct dehydration.

The recommended volume of ORS for children with mild to moderate dehydration is 75-100 ml/kg over 4 hours.

For a 9 kg baby, this translates to 675-900 ml of ORS over 4 hours. However, considering that the child is described as feeding well and thirsty, a volume at the lower end of the range (400-700 ml) may be appropriate.

The child's ability to feed and thirst indicate mild dehydration, and the skin pinch return time of 4 seconds suggests moderate dehydration. Therefore, administering 400-700 ml of ORS in the first 4 hours would be appropriate to rehydrate the child and correct dehydration.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

(A) 200-400 ml of ORS to be given in the first 4 hours:

This option suggests administering a relatively lower volume of oral rehydration solution (ORS) in the first 4 hours. However, the child's weight, thirst, and skin pinch return time indicate mild to moderate dehydration, which may require a higher volume of fluid replacement to adequately rehydrate the child.

(C) 700-900 ml of ORS to be given in the first 4 hours:

This option suggests administering a relatively higher volume of ORS in the first 4 hours. While aggressive fluid replacement may be necessary for children with severe dehydration, it may lead to overhydration in children with mild to moderate dehydration. Overhydration can potentially exacerbate electrolyte imbalances and increase the risk of fluid overload complications.

(D) In addition to the usual fluid intake, 100-200 ml should be given after each loose stool:

This option suggests a strategy of replacing fluids lost through diarrhoea by administering additional fluid after each loose stool. While this approach may help prevent dehydration, it may not provide sufficient fluid replacement to address existing dehydration or prevent its progression.

In summary, option (B) 400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first 4 hours is the most appropriate treatment for the 9 kg baby with diarrhea described in the scenario. This volume of ORS provides adequate fluid replacement to address the child's dehydration while minimizing the risk of overhydration.

Reference: Park's Preventive and social medicine, 27th EDITION Pg 266

questions.text: All are true regarding folliculogenesis and ovulation except:
questions.solution:
Option A: 'The cohort of the growing follicles undergoes a process of development and differentiation which takes about 85 days and is spread over 3 ovarian cycles.

Option B: It is not clear as to how many and which of the primordial follicles amidst several thousands are recruited for a particular cycle. It is presumed that about 20 antral follicles (about 5-10 per ovary) proceed to develop in each cycle. The initial recruitment and growth of primordial follicles are not under the control of any hormone. After a certain stage (2-5 mm in size) the growth and differentiation of primordial follicles are under the control of FSH. Unless the follicles are rescued by FSH at this stage, they undergo atresia'

Option C: Role of AMH (anti mullerian hormone) AMH inhibits initial recruitment of primordial follicles into the pool of growing follicles. It also decreases responsiveness of follicles to FSH. AMH plays an important role for mono follicular development and ovulation.

Option D: The basic prerequisite in the ovulatory cycle is fluctuating levels of E2. If for any reason the E2 levels become static, anovulation is a rule (as in PCOS)

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false for Mondor's disease?
questions.solution:
Mondor's Disease -

  • There is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the anterior chest wall and breast.
  • Patient presents with pain and a tender firm cord in the region of the involved vein.
  • Frequently involved veins include the lateral thoracic vein and the thoracoepigastric vein.
  • This benign, self-limited (usually resolves within 4 to 6 weeks) disorder is not indicative of cancer.
  • Rarely, the presentation is bilateral, and most women have no evidence of thrombophlebitis in other anatomic sites.
  • When the diagnosis is uncertain, or when a mass is present near the tender cord, biopsy is indicated.
  • Treatment -Anti-inflammatory medications and warm compresses.
  • When symptoms persist or are refractory to therapy, excision of the involved vein segment may be considered.

questions.text: What approach to heart is commonly used for cardiopulmonary bypass?
questions.solution:
Surgical approach to the heart

  • The heart is approached mainly by a median sternotomy. The incision is made from the suprasternal notch to the lower end of the xiphisternum. The sternum is divided and retracted to expose the thymus superiorly and the pericardium inferiorly. The thymus, although atrophic in adults, often remains relatively vascular.
  • The thymus and pleurae are dissected from the pericardium and the pericardium is opened.
  • Before cannulation for CPB, the patient is fully heparinised.

Other incisions that can be used include left or right anterolateral thoracotomy for minimally invasive operations or for specific operations on the descending aorta.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 59, Cardiac Surgery, Pg: 944.

questions.text: Where is the most common skeletal metastasis seen in the patient of breast tumour?
questions.solution:
Skeletal metastases occurs via the bloodstream in breast carcinoma. The commonly involved sites in order of frequency include -

  • Lumbar vertebrae - most common
  • Femur
  • Thoracic vertebrae
  • Ribs
  • Skull

The deposits are generally more osteolytic than osteoblastic.

Metastases may also commonly occur in the liver, lungs and brain and, occasionally, the adrenal glands and ovaries via the bloodstream.

Reference: Love & Bailey short practice of surgery, chapter: 53, Edition: 27th, Pg: 873

choices.text: Polycystin-1 and polycystin-2 play a critical role
Visible haematuria occurs in up to 40% of patients with ADPKD
Hypertension is the least common manifestation of ADPKD

questions.text: Not true regarding ADPKD?
questions.solution:
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)-

  • Due to mutations in Polycystin-1 (chromosome 16) and polycystin-2 (chromosome 4).

Features -

  • Renal size increases with age resulting in a flank or abdominal mass in some patients.
  • Cysts contain clear fluid, thick brown material or coagulated blood.
  • Visible haematuria occurs in up to 40% of patients with ADPKD.
  • Cyst haemorrhage is a frequent complication with or without haematuria, depending on whether the cyst communicates with the collecting system or not.
  • Hypertension is the most common manifestation of ADPKD and a major contributor to renal disease progression and cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.
  • After the age of 20 years, most patients are hypertensive.
  • Associated with intracranial aneurysms in 10% of cases.

VHL disease is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that is characterised by multiple pathologies, including clear-cell RCC (ccRCC), pheochromocytoma, retinal angiomas and haemangioblastomas of the brainstem, cerebellum or spinal cord.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1482.

questions.text: All of the following are indications for circumcision except?
questions.solution:
Ritual circumcision is contraindicated in infants with hypospadias because the foreskin is often required for the reconstruction.

The medical indications for circumcision are:

  • Phimosis. This term is often wrongly applied to describe a normal, non-retractile foreskin. True phimosis is seen as a whitish scarring of the foreskin and is rare before 5 years of age. It is caused by the localised skin disease balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO), which also affects the glans penis and can cause urethral meatal stenosis.
  • Recurrent balanoposthitis. A single episode of inflammation of the foreskin, sometimes with a purulent discharge, is not uncommon and usually resolves spontaneously; antibiotics are sometimes needed. Recurrent attacks are unusual but may be an indication for circumcision.
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection. Circumcision is occasionally justified in boys with an abnormal upper urinary tract anomaly and recurrent urinary infection. It may also help boys with spina bifida who need to perform clean intermittent urethral catheterisation.

Reference: Bailey and love's short practice of surgery, 27th edition, Page - 126, 127

questions.text: A 35-year-old female came to the surgical OPD with swelling in the lower abdomen for 5 months. Swelling increases in size on coughing. Patient had been operated on for abdominal hysterectomy 4 years ago. She is also a known case of rheumatoid arthritis for the last 10 years, and is on medications. What would be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient has been complaining of lower abdominal swelling for 5 months, which increases on coughing. So,cimpulse on coughing is positive, which is the key feature of a hernia. Patient had an operative history 4 years back which is associated with the patient's medical history of rheumatoid arthritis. So, the patient may be on an immunosuppressant or steroid medications, which can be the causative factor for incisional hernia.
  • Incisional hernias arise through a defect in the musculofascial layers of the abdominal wall in the region of a postoperative scar. Thus, they may appear anywhere on the abdominal surface.
  • Factors predisposing to their development are patient factors (obesity, general poor healing due to malnutrition, immunosuppression or steroid therapy, chronic cough, cancer), wound factors (poor quality tissues, wound infection) and surgical factors (inappropriate suture material, incorrect suture placement).
  • Incisional hernia-
    • Incidence 10-50% after surgery.
    • Causation due to patient, wound and surgeon factors.
    • Wide variation in size.
    • Often multiple defects within the same scar.
    • Obstruction is common but strangulation is rare.
    • Open and laparoscopic repairs possible.

Option A: Ovarian cyst can present with lower abdominal swelling but does not present with impulse on coughing. So, it cannot be the answer.

Option C: Abdominal lipoma also cannot present with impulse on coughing, so operative and medical history are insignificant for abdominal lipoma. So, it cannot be the answer.

Option D: Umbilical hernia can present with impulse on coughing, but past medical and operative history are insignificant for umbilical hernia. Umbilical hernia usually occurs in the childhood and presents with the umbilical region swelling and not lower abdominal swelling.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 64, Page Number-1077.

questions.text: A 29 years old male presents with complaints of worsening of intense urinary frequency, urgency and small quantity voids. Cystogram image is as below. What is the spot diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Retrograde cystography shows a thimble bladder (exceedingly contracted bladder). This is seen in tuberculous cystitis.

  • Secondary to renal tuberculosis.
  • Early tuberculosis of the bladder starts around the ureteric orifice or trigone.
  • The earliest evidence is pallor of the mucosa due to submucous oedema.
  • Subsequently, tubercles may be seen.
  • In longstanding cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced causing thimble bladder.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1472.

questions.text: A young male patient had urethral injury after road traffic accident. Following procedure has been performed. What is the likely procedure?
questions.solution:
(a)Percutaneous puncture of the bladder with passage of a guidewire into the bladder followed by dilatation of the track over the guidewire.

(b)Thereby allowing placement of a catheter into the bladder.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 83, The urinary bladder, Pg: 1509.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false for Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Meckel's diverticulum

  • A Meckel's diverticulum is a persistent remnant of the vitellointestinal duct and is present in about 2% of the population.
  • It is found on the antimesenteric side of the ileum, commonly approximately 60 cm from the ileocaecal valve and is classically 5 cm long.
  • A Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum.
  • It contains all three coats of the bowel wall and has its own blood supply.
  • It may be vulnerable to obstruction and inflammation in the same way as the appendix; indeed, when a normal appendix is found at surgery for suspected appendicitis, a Meckel's diverticulum should be looked for by examining the small bowel, particularly if free fluid or pus is found.
  • In approximately 20% of cases, the mucosa of a Meckel's diverticulum contains heterotopic epithelium of gastric, colonic or pancreatic type.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 74, Edition: 28th, Pg: 1312

questions.text: Single most important prognostic index in melanoma?
questions.solution:
• The presence of lymph node metastases is the single most important prognostic index in melanoma, outweighing both tumour and host factors. The number of affected nodes and the presence of extranodal extension are also significant outcome predictors.
  • Once regional nodes are clinically involved, 70-85% of patients will have occult distant metastases.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, CHAPTER 45 Pathophysiology of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, Pg: 658

questions.text: What is Terson's syndrome?

The combination of subarachnoid hemorrhage and vitreous haemorrhage (subhyaloid) is known as Terson's Syndrome.

questions.text: What is the Duke's classification for a rectal growth extending into the extrarectal tissue without regional lymph node metastasis?
questions.solution:
Dukes' staging

  • A: The growth is limited to the rectal wall (15%). The prognosis is excellent (>90% 5- year survival).
  • B: The growth extends to the extrarectal tissues, but without metastasis to the regional lymph nodes (35%). The prognosis is reasonable (70% 5-year survival).
  • C: There are secondary deposits in the regional lymph nodes (50%). These are subdivided into C1, in which the local pararectal lymph nodes alone are involved, and C2, in which the nodes accompanying the supplying blood vessels to their origin from the aorta are involved. This does not take into account cases that have metastasised beyond the regional lymph nodes or by way of the venous system. The prognosis is poor (40% 5-year survival).
    • A stage D is often included, which was not described by Dukes. This stage signifies the presence of widespread metastases, usually hepatic. Other staging systems have been developed (e.g. Astler-Coller, TNM) to improve prognostic accuracy, with the tumour-node-metastasis (TNM) classification now recognised internationally as the optimum staging classification.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter 79, Edition 28th, Pg: 1407
